34.title: How to set up crypto wallet to withdraw ICY
34.description: To withdraw ICY to Vietnam Bank or other fiat, you need set up 2 types of wallet in advance. This guide will show you how to setup crypto wallet.
34.spr_content: - **Objective**: Withdraw ICY to Vietnam Bank or convert to fiat. <hr />- **Requirement**: Set up two wallet types: <hr />  - **On-chain wallet**: <hr />    - Non-custodial.<hr />    - Example: Coinbase, Metamask.<hr />    - Purpose: Receive ICY, swap ICY to USDT.<hr />  - **Custodial wallet**: <hr />    - Example: Binance.<hr />    - Purpose: Convert USDT to VND.<hr />- **Instructions**:<hr />  - **Coinbase Wallet Setup**:<hr />    1. Install extension from Coinbase website (Chrome or Firefox only).<hr />    2. Access wallet via extension icon.<hr />    3. Create a new wallet if none exists.<hr />    4. Secure wallet with seed phrase.<hr />      - Store phrase securely; do not share.<hr />      - Confirm seed phrase upon setup.<hr />    5. Set a password for wallet access.<hr />  <hr />  - **Binance Account Creation**:<hr />    1. Download Binance app on mobile.<hr />    2. Select “Crypto Novice” mode during setup.<hr />    3. Create account.<hr />    4. Set up a passkey for easy login.<hr />    5. Provide personal information for identity verification.<hr />    6. Verify identity with necessary documentation.<hr />- **Follow guidelines** in the provided link for withdrawal process.

35.title: Quantization for large language models
35.description: As large language models (LLMs) continue to evolve, their parameter counts grow exponentially, with some models reaching trillions of parameters. This exponential growth presents significant challenges for deployment on edge devices and in resource-constrained environments due to extensive memory and computational requirements. Quantization emerges as a crucial technique to reduce model footprint while preserving acceptable performance.
35.spr_content: - LLMs evolve with exponential growth in parameters, reaching trillions.<hr />- Deployment on edge devices faces challenges due to high memory and computational needs.<hr />- Quantization is crucial for reducing model footprints while maintaining performance.<hr />  <hr />- **Quantization Overview**  <hr />  - Transforms weights and activations from high to low precision, e.g., 32-bit to 8-bit.<hr />  - Benefits:  <hr />    - Reduces model size, memory consumption, and storage.<hr />    - Enhances energy efficiency.<hr />  - Precision loss can occur, but remains acceptable within thresholds.<hr />  <hr />- **Quantization Methods**  <hr />  - **Post-training Quantization (PTQ)**: Applied post-training for inference.<hr />  - **Quantization-aware Training (QAT)**: Incorporates quantization during training for accuracy.<hr /><hr />- **Quantization Process**  <hr />  - Types: Linear Quantization (two modes).  <hr />    - **Symmetric**: Zero point is zero. Efficient computationally, possible accuracy loss.<hr />    - **Asymmetric**: Non-zero zero point. Higher accuracy, less efficient computation.<hr /><hr />- **Asymmetric Quantization Formula**  <hr />  - \( q = \text{round}(s * w + z) \)  <hr />  - \( q \): quantized value, \( s \): scale factor, \( w \): original value, \( z \): zero point.<hr />  <hr />- **Steps of Quantization**  <hr />  1. **Data Range Determination**: Identify min/max of dataset.<hr />  2. **Scale Factor Calculation**: <hr />     - \( s = \frac{q_{\text{max}} - q_{\text{min}}}{w_{\text{max}} - w_{\text{min}}} \)<hr />  3. **Zero Point Calculation**: <hr />     - \( z = q_{\text{min}} - \text{round}(s * w_{\text{min}}) \)<hr />  4. **Quantization Application**: Apply the formula to get quantized values.<hr />  5. **De-quantization**: <hr />     - \( w = \frac{q - z}{s} \)<hr />     - Errors from mapping continuous to discrete values: termed quantization error.<hr /><hr />- **Quantized Model File Format**  <hr />  - 2023's GGUF (Generic GPT Unified Format) improves storage and execution for quantized models.<hr />  - Goals: efficiency, compatibility, scalability for varying model architectures.<hr /><hr />- **Model Naming Conventions (e.g., HuggingFace)**  <hr />  - Indicates quantization method and bit representation: `author/{model_name}:q{bits}_{method}`.<hr /><hr />- **Conclusion**  <hr />  - Quantization is pivotal for LLM optimization, facilitating efficient deployment on resource-limited devices.

36.title: Frontend Report March 2025
36.description: March 2025 brings critical frontend updates! Learn about the Next.js security exploit you must patch nows. Explore TypeScript's upcoming 10x speed boost with Corsa, React Router's game-changing middleware, and why prefetching can surprisingly slow down your site. Plus: CSS functions are finally here, new in Chrome 133, Node.js is dropping Corepack, and TanStack Start finds an official deployment home!
36.spr_content: - **Common React Libraries Architecture**: Core logic + bindings (hooks/components). <hr />- **Observer Pattern**: Notifies React of changes; uses `useSyncExternalStore` and custom hooks.<hr />- **Ditching Redux**: Replace with caching; modern React meets state needs with `useState` and custom hooks.<hr />- **React 19 Cache API**: Caches data fetches, reducing redundant requests; improves performance; enables preloading.<hr />- **Next.js Middleware Vulnerability**: CVE-2025-29927; security bypass via `x-middleware-subrequest`; update to secure versions.<hr />- **Next.js 15.2 Updates**: Enhanced error handling; decoupled UI and metadata rendering; faster page loads.<hr />- **Traffic Handling in Next.js**: Pre-rendering limitations; dedicated servers outpace VPS performance in high traffic.<hr />- **Next.js Alternatives**: Custom solutions offer simplicity over Next.js; assess framework fit.<hr />- **Tailwind Trade-offs**: Fast shipping vs. long-term maintainability challenges.<hr />- **CSS Functions**: Introduces real functions; enhances complex logic in styles.<hr />- **Prefetching Pitfalls**: Can harm loading speed; manage via post-load JavaScript hints.<hr />- **React 2025 Trends**: Standardization of Server Components, improved data fetching, rise of Full-Stack React.<hr />- **TypeScript Speed Boost**: New Go-based compiler; promises radical performance improvements.<hr />- **Corepack Discontinuation**: Node.js votes to stop bundling; impacts package manager evolution.<hr />- **TanStack Start Partnership**: Netlify as official deployment partner; zero-config deployments.<hr />- **TanStack Form**: Production-ready for multiple frameworks; focuses on type safety and async validation.<hr />- **React Router v7 Middleware**: Enables route interception for checks and analytics.<hr />- **TypeScript Enhancements**: Granular return type checks; improved Node.js ESM support.<hr />- **Chrome 133 Features**: Enhances `attr()` functionality; enables dynamic styling with container queries.<hr />- **Ongoing JavaScript Fatigue**: Persistent challenges with evolving frameworks and technologies.<hr />- **React Signals Debate**: Discussion on integrating signals into React state management.<hr />- **Local-first Approach**: Future potential for localized data storage, but presents challenges.

37.title: Secure and transparent uptime monitoring with Upptime and GitHub secrets
37.description: Discover how Dwarves Foundation uses Upptime and GitHub Actions for transparent public uptime monitoring while securely keeping tabs on internal services.
37.spr_content: - Importance of uptime monitoring for all services (public and private).<hr />- Necessity of transparency for public services; user trust is vital.<hr />- Need for security and privacy for internal tools and sensitive APIs.<hr />- Risks of exposing internal endpoints: <hr />  - Security vulnerabilities increase with exposure.<hr />  - Internal infrastructure details, if revealed, can be exploited.<hr />  - Unwanted scanning or attacks from bots.<hr />  - Complexity in checks requiring specific authentication details.<hr />- Upptime as the monitoring solution: open-source, GitHub Actions-based.<hr />- GitOps model promotes collaboration and traceable configuration.<hr />- Cost-effective usage of GitHub Actions and self-hosted runners for control.<hr />- Advantages of automation in monitoring and generating status updates.<hr />- `.upptimerc.yml` file centralizes configuration:<hr />  - Public APIs directly listed.<hr />  - Sensitive internal APIs hidden using GitHub Secrets (e.g., `${{ secrets.SECRET_API_URL }}`).<hr />- GitHub Actions workflows manage automation:<hr />  - `uptime.yml`: Runs every 5 minutes, checks URLs, records status, creates Issues on downtime.<hr />  - Daily workflows (`response-time.yml`, `summary.yml`, `site.yml`): Process data and build/update status webpage.<hr />- Dynamic status page (`status.d.foundation`) reflects real-time data:<hr />  - Public data fetched securely from repository.<hr />  - Sensitive API details remain hidden.<hr />- Effective balance between transparent monitoring for public and secure oversight for private services.<hr />- Simple, code-based management enhances overall operational efficiency.

38.title: Labs Team
38.description: This is our Labs team homepage, where we list out the latest advances in our engineering team, our publications, events & workshops, as well as frequently asked questions on who and what team labs are.
38.spr_content: - Labs Team Overview: Passionate about emerging technologies; diverse backgrounds; focused on exploration and understanding for a better future.<hr />  <hr />- Collaboration: Exchange insights; assess innovative applications; partner with consulting teams; hands-on immersion with technologies.<hr /><hr />- Goals: Explore trending technologies; identify potential innovations; roadmap focused on shaping a promising future.<hr /><hr />- Membership Onboarding: Primarily through recommendations; contributions in tech discussions on Discord encouraged; mentoring provided; one-month topic exploration; technical report presentation required.<hr /><hr />- Topic Proposals: Only labs and consulting team members can propose; non-members can share insights on Discord; notable ideas rewarded with ICY tokens.<hr /><hr />- Reward System: ICY tokens awarded based on contribution impact; enhances knowledge base and drives innovation; guidelines available for contribution valuation.<hr /><hr />- Events: Regular catchups to consolidate findings and progress; showcased technologies like DuckDB; demos include NYC taxi data processing and analytics on various data sets.

39.title: Design Sprint
39.description: Design sprint mostly applied to the Exploration phase. Friday is usually Education event or Lab projects at Dwarves Design, learning and continuous professional and personal development are in the core of our DNA. No one wants to settle, everyone wants to take the next step forward.
39.spr_content: - **Design Sprint**: A four-day intensive process focused on solving critical business problems through design, prototyping, and customer testing. Primarily applied during the Exploration phase.<hr /><hr />- **Purpose**: Collaborate and make rapid advancements on a problem using design thinking methods.<hr /><hr />- **Stages**:<hr />  - **Day 1 - Map & Sketch**: Identify the problem; gather insights from experts; define key questions; prioritize ideas through Note-and-Vote; map initial customer journey; sketch potential solutions.<hr />  - **Day 2 - Decide & Storyboard**: Select and refine one concept; vote on appealing elements; outline a 6-step customer experience; create a coherent storyboard with low-fidelity wireframes for user flow.<hr />  - **Day 3 - Prototype**: Assemble the prototype; assign roles (Maker, Collector, Writer, Stitcher, Engagement Coordinator) based on skill sets; utilize tools like Sketch, Adobe XD, Invision for wireframing.<hr />  - **Day 4 - Test**: Conduct user tests with qualitative interviews (5-8 participants); gather feedback via notes and post-its; analyze responses to derive insights.<hr /><hr />- **Roles**:<hr />  - **Facilitator**: Oversees the sprint direction.<hr />  - **Recorder**: Documents the process and outcomes.<hr />  - **Product Owner**: Final decision-maker on product vision.<hr /><hr />- **Materials**: Post-it Notes, Sharpies, blank paper, whiteboard, markers, voting stickers, easel pad.<hr /><hr />- **Room Setup**: Spacious environment with whiteboards for collaborative work and sketch display.<hr /><hr />- **Iteration**: Multiple sprints may be needed in the Exploration phase for optimal solutions; Agile methods continue in the Detailed Design phase for finalization and user testing before client handoff. <hr /><hr />- **Culture**: Emphasis on continuous learning and development at Dwarves Design; strive for improvement and innovation.

40.title: Lean Canvas
40.description: Lean Canvas is an adaptation of Business Model Canvas by Alexander Osterwalder which Ash Maurya created in the Lean Startup spirit (Fast, Concise and Effective startup). Lean Canvas promises an actionable and entrepreneur-focused business plan. It focuses on problems, solutions, key metrics, and competitive advantages.
40.spr_content: - Lean Canvas: Entrepreneur-focused business planning tool, derived from Business Model Canvas.<hr />- Emphasizes actionable insights and rapid development for startups.<hr />- Key components: problem, solution, customer segments, unique value proposition.<hr /><hr />1. **Problem:** Identify the central frustrations of consumers; articulate jobs they need to do and associated pains.<hr />   - Existing alternatives: Analyze current competitors and methods; assess failures to serve customer needs.<hr /><hr />2. **Customer Segments:** Define 3-4 key personas affected by identified problems.<hr />   - Consider job titles, industries, demographics, and salary ranges.<hr />   - Early adopters are crucial; they shape first iterations of the business.<hr /><hr />3. **Unique Value Proposition:** Clearly state what differentiates the product and highlights its value.<hr />   - Communicate target segment, primary problem, benefits received, and unique delivery method in one sentence.<hr />   - Structure: “We help (who?) achieve (what benefit?) by (how?).”<hr /><hr />4. **Solution:** Articulate specific solutions addressing consumer problems.<hr />   - Define essential features that position the product as superior in meeting needs.<hr /><hr />5. **Channels:** Determine effective methods for consumer interaction and promotion.<hr />   - Explore print ads, social media, events, or word-of-mouth strategies.<hr /><hr />6. **Revenue Streams:** Outline income generation strategies.<hr />   - Include pricing models, subscription fees, ad sales, or asset sales.<hr /><hr />7. **Cost Structure:** Assess costs associated with launching and sustaining the product.<hr />   - Consider development, marketing, and employee expenses.<hr /><hr />8. **Key Metrics:** Establish methods for measuring consumer engagement and product usage.<hr />   - Utilize metrics like SASS, AARRR, user downloads, and quotes.<hr /><hr />9. **Unfair Advantage:** Identify competitive edges that ensure reliability and consumer confidence.<hr />   - Leverage existing resources or capabilities that are hard to replicate.

41.title: aarrr
41.description: We use the AARRR framework to measure and optimize every phase of a product by optimizing it through the insane focus on one metric at a time.
41.spr_content: - **AARRR Framework**: Tool for measuring and optimizing product phases; focuses on one metric at a time.<hr />- **Five Phases**: <hr />  - **Acquisition**: Attracting users.<hr />  - **Activation**: Ensuring users have a great first experience.<hr />  - **Retention**: Keeping users engaged over time.<hr />  - **Referral**: Encouraging users to recommend the product.<hr />  - **Revenue**: Generating income from users.<hr />- **Purpose**: Tracks product performance and long-term growth stability.<hr />- **Importance**: Summarizes critical growth metrics for startups; offers simplicity and actionability.<hr />- **Application Steps**:<hr />  1. **Choose Phase**: Identify the focus area for improvement.<hr />  2. **Gather Data**: Collect quantitative (analytics) and qualitative (user feedback) data to establish a baseline metric.<hr />  3. **Validate Problem**: Conduct user interviews/usability tests to confirm problems and understand root causes.<hr />  4. **Ideate Solutions**: Collaborate with stakeholders to brainstorm ideas and gain early buy-in.

42.title: The Adjacent Possible
42.description: The concept of the adjacent possible originates from Stuart Kauffman and his work on biological evolution.
42.spr_content: - **Adjacent Possible**: Concept originating from Stuart Kauffman regarding innovation and exploration within immediate boundaries.<hr />- **Innovation**: Expands knowledge, capabilities, and access to resources; allows delivery of new products, organizations, and ideas.<hr />- **Expansion**: Requires stepping beyond current boundaries, focusing on nearby possibilities for growth.<hr />- **Complex Adaptive Systems**: Kauffman's insights apply to biological and human-made systems.<hr />- **The Actual**: Current state of a system with its components and connections; defines existing knowledge and resources.<hr />- **The Possible**: Realm of capabilities that can be created by combining existing elements in novel ways.<hr />- **Path Dependency**: Progress builds upon historical developments, taking time to evolve through multiple stages.<hr />- **Social Learning**: Key driver of human progress; allows sharing and building upon ideas across time and space.<hr />- **Five Paths to Progress**: <hr />  1. **Sharing**: Distribution of existing knowledge, vital for social learning but does not create new progress.<hr />  2. **Science**: Expansion of human knowledge; foundational for future practical advancements.<hr />  3. **Invention**: Pursuit of original ideas; varies in feasibility and impact on progress.<hr />  4. **Discovery**: Unexpected observations leading to new understanding; situated in the adjacent possible.<hr />  5. **Innovation**: Intentional development of solutions; encompasses the realm of attainable new possibilities.<hr /><hr />- **Integrative Nature**: Paths to progress are interconnected and can occur simultaneously or sequentially; success relies on collective efforts and diverse contributions. <hr />- **Technological Role**: Technology's impact on innovation as an enabler or hindrance will be explored further.

43.title: Setting The Budget
43.description: After a project has been loosely defined, the profit generating, or cost savings, potential should be estimated. Refining scope and budget will cost time and money. Knowing the potential reward will ensure that the research, design and planning effort stays within perspective.
43.spr_content: 1. **Budget Importance**: Setting a project budget is crucial for viable product development.<hr />2. **Initial Ignorance**: Early project stages exhibit maximum uncertainty; requirements, scope, market, and technical aspects are unformed.<hr />3. **Iterative Refinement**: Project scope and budget should evolve through defined steps along a budget roadmap.<hr />4. **Profit Potential**: After initial definition, estimate potential profits or savings to maintain perspective on research, design, and planning efforts.<hr />5. **Early Estimation Techniques**: Utilize initial requirements, historical data, and intuition for broad cost estimates (e.g., $50K-$100K).<hr />6. **Scope Reevaluation**: If estimates exceed expectations, revisit and realign scope with requirements.<hr />7. **Research, Design, Planning (RDP)**: If estimates are acceptable, proceed to RDP for deeper product definition.<hr />8. **User Story Mapping**: Create story maps to outline user tasks, defining a minimum viable product (MVP).<hr />9. **Feature Estimation**: Estimate development effort in days and use sketches/wireframes for clarity; qualifiy features by context and usage frequency.<hr />10. **Refined Estimate Outcomes**: RDP typically results in a refined estimate; increased costs reflect gained knowledge and reduced risk.<hr />11. **Decision Gate**: Decide post-RDP whether to proceed with development based on refined estimates.<hr />12. **Budget Constraint in Development**: Begin development with RDP's estimate as a constraint, creating a backlog of prioritized development stories.<hr />13. **Backlog Tracking**: Weekly monitor and update the progress and projected costs of stories, revising scope as necessary to maintain budget.<hr />14. **Predictable Delivery**: Aim for final release within established time and budget, adhering to refined estimates throughout the project cycle.

44.title: How to work with clients
44.description: What skills that an engineer should have in order to work with client effectively?
44.spr_content: **Skills for Effective Client Interaction:**<hr />1. Strong technical foundational knowledge: understanding of unit, integration, and system testing; proficient in software debugging.<hr />2. Detail-oriented approach: meticulousness in work enhances quality.<hr />3. Enhanced communication capabilities: intermediate to upper-intermediate proficiency in English, both written and spoken, is essential.<hr />4. Problem-solving aptitude: logical thinking to navigate issues effectively.<hr />5. Strategic work planning: ability to organize tasks efficiently.<hr />6. Collaborative teamwork: essential for unified project efforts.<hr />7. Project management proficiency: skills to oversee project timelines and resources.<hr />8. Reliability: consistent delivery of high-quality results is crucial.<hr /><hr />**Current Challenges in Client Engagement:**<hr />1. Language barriers: difficulties with verbal and written English impede communication.<hr />2. Inattention to detail: inconsistencies often result in subpar work quality.<hr />3. Ineffective work planning: leads to disorganization and missed deadlines.<hr />4. Inconsistent output: fluctuating quality in deliverables affects client trust.<hr />5. Team cohesion issues: case example of Dong Nguyen highlights synchronization problems with remote teams.<hr />6. Emotional intelligence deficit: lack of EQ undermines interpersonal relationships and client rapport.

45.title: Annual bonus for sales
45.description: Guide to calculate annual bonus for sales
45.spr_content: - Annual bonus for sales: two components: new deals and previous deals.<hr />- New deals: bonus tiered based on deployment team size over 12 months.<hr />  - Low Tier: **$600 to $4,000** for team size **4-8**.<hr />  - Medium Tier: **$9,000 to $60,000** for team size **12-20**.<hr />  - High Tier: **$72,000 to $96,000** for team size **24-32**.<hr />- Previous deals: earn **2%** on old commission.<hr />- Upselling counts as new money.

46.title: Are You Helping
46.description: In a recent post I wrote "Inner Circle", I expounded on the importance of contribution and value in relation to a person's work or performance.
46.spr_content: - Competitive business demands understanding of employee value and performance.<hr />- Contribution and value are key metrics of work performance.<hr />- Essential question: "Are you helping?" evaluates individual contributions.<hr />- Employee output reveals their value and performance level.<hr />- Salary reflects a social contract of anticipated value produced, not actual worth.<hr />- Job title indicates work scope, not intrinsic value.<hr />- Lack of value production leads to negative perceptions and workplace conflicts.<hr />- Individuals not meeting performance expectations can be labeled as overpaid.<hr />- Overpayment results in heightened expectations and scrutiny from peers and supervisors.<hr />- Employee value is primarily measured by contribution to organizational success.<hr />- True employee worth transcends salary and title.<hr />- Organizations must focus on employees' ability to aid success for accurate evaluations. <hr />- Reiterate: Are you helping?

47.title: Writing Management Objectives In Smart
47.description: Use S.M.A.R.T goal to define management objectives
47.spr_content: - S.M.A.R.T. goals concept originated in George T. Doran's 1981 paper.<hr />- S.M.A.R.T. stands for Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound.<hr />- Specific: Define clear objectives; address who, what, when, where, which, and why.<hr />- Example of specificity: Transform "Make a cross-browser layout" into "<www.site.com> must be equally displayed in browsers IE6+, Opera 6+, Firefox 2+."<hr />- Measurable: Establish metrics for tracking progress; include milestones.<hr />- Example of measurability: Change "Increase traffic" to "Must achieve 2,000 visitors per day."<hr />- Achievable: Assess goal's attainability; inspire motivation; identify necessary skills and tools.<hr />- Relevant: Ensure goal aligns with broader business objectives; focus on meaningful impact.<hr />- Time-bound: Set realistic deadlines; create urgency with specific timeframes.<hr />- Example of time-bound: Change "Make section 'Contact Us' for a demonstration by tomorrow" to "Make section 'Contact Us' for demonstration by noon 6/10/2016."<hr />- Practical example of a S.M.A.R.T. goal: "In 3 months, achieve 50% increase in email blog subscribers by boosting Facebook ad budget on high-performing posts."

48.title: Avoid Burn Out
48.description: Burnout happens like burning the candle at both ends. But you get to select what time to pull the plug and replace with a new one.
48.spr_content: - Burnout vs. stress: Burnout is deeper, representing physical and emotional exhaustion.<hr />- Impact: Burnout diminishes productivity and erodes motivation, creativity, and job satisfaction.<hr />- Symptoms: Feelings of monotony, dissatisfaction, and existential questioning about work.<hr />- Burnout permeates all aspects of life: work, relationships, friendships, and personal passions.<hr />- Misconception: Burnout isn’t solely a result of job demands; it's a feeling of ineffectiveness and wasted time.<hr />- Cures: Attempting to "try harder" is ineffective; recognize that even machines need rest.<hr />- Importance of early signs: Identifying symptoms is critical for preventing escalation into deeper burnout.<hr />- Strategies: Seek help, adjust workload, communicate feelings, take breaks, indulge in joyous activities.<hr />- Work-life balance: Essential for personal interests; life is not just about work obligations.<hr />- Self-ownership: Set limits and take responsibility for actions to combat burnout effectively.<hr />- Metaphor: Burnout is burning a candle at both ends; one must choose when to extinguish it and renew.

49.title: Hiring For Operations Team
49.description: Operations is a very sensitive area of the company, so be very picky. A great ops person can dramatically improve the way your company works and make your life a lot easier.
49.spr_content: - Operations is universally sensitive and pivotal to company function.<hr />- A strong operations person enhances organizational efficiency, simplifies processes.<hr />- Operations challenges are largely consistent across industries; specialized knowledge is secondary.<hr />- An effective operations leader connects and mediates functional areas.<hr />- Hands-on experience in IT, HR, accounting, recruiting, infrastructure, marketing, and sales is crucial; lack thereof is a significant handicap.<hr />- Operations leaders must be willing to engage directly, avoiding a detached, "white glove" approach.<hr />- Judiciously allowing team members to encounter challenges fosters growth and learning.<hr />- Proactive planning is essential; operations leaders maintain contingency plans for every scenario.<hr />- Those uncomfortable with messiness are ill-suited for operations.<hr />- Operations professionals function as the company's protective force, facilitating sustainable growth and bearing the brunt of challenges.<hr />- Successful operations require navigating obstacles, ensuring discipline, and managing issues quietly.<hr />- A strong network of suppliers and specialists is key for operational success; seeking expert advice is crucial.<hr />- Fluency in the "language" of each professional within the organization enhances collaboration and credibility.<hr />- Earning respect and credibility from the board and CEO is critical for operational effectiveness.<hr />- The role is challenging, and achieving perfection in relational dynamics is nearly impossible; effectiveness improves with team credibility and respect.

50.title: Bunk license check
50.description: Glice is a Golang license and dependency checker, providing detailed insights into dependencies and their licenses
50.spr_content: - Tool: Glice<hr />- Purpose: Golang license and dependency checker<hr />- Outputs: <hr />  - List of all dependencies (standard library and third-party)<hr />  - Frequency of usage for each dependency<hr />  - Corresponding license information<hr />  - Saves license files in directory: /licenses<hr />- Installation Steps:<hr />  - Clone to local workspace: `$ go get github.com/ribice/glice`<hr />  - Install to $GOBIN: `$ go install github.com/ribice/glice`<hr />- Execution Command: `$ glice`

51.title: Adjust The Way We Work In Basecamp Style
51.description: Our path with Basecamp didn't cross by accident. Years ago, we embarked on the Slack community and had it applied for internal communication. And project management on another tool, where documents & files are in G-suite.
51.spr_content: - Remote team structure enhances autonomy and productivity.<hr />- Eliminates commuting time, allowing personalized work environments.<hr />- Integrated tools like Basecamp streamline project management and communication.<hr />- Initial reliance on Slack and G-suite had limitations in focus and productivity.<hr />- Frequent distractions from messages and memes necessitated a shift to a focused platform.<hr />- Basecamp emerged as the chosen solution for structured team engagement.<hr />- Transitioning to Basecamp required adjustments to communication habits.<hr />- Initial usage was limited; gradually became central for collaboration and project tracking.<hr />- **Organizational Structure:**<hr />  - **Woodlands/HQ:** Central announcements, resources, team chat.<hr />  - **Teams:** Custom spaces for activities, meetings, and discussions.<hr />  - **Projects:** Detailed project management with assigned responsibilities, organized conversations in campfires.<hr />- **Automatic Check-Ins:** Foster engagement through informal questions and daily reflections on progress.<hr />- **Todos Feature:** Allows task management with clear assignments, deadlines, and notes.<hr />- **Schedule:** Synchronizes team and personal calendars for efficient meeting management.<hr />- **Message Board:** Shares important updates, project insights, and encourages focused discussions.<hr />- **Docs & Files:** Organized storage for team assets, with support for cloud integration.<hr />- **Quick Navigation:** Shortcuts facilitate fast access to necessary information.<hr />- **Transparency:** Activity tab keeps everyone informed without overwhelming details.<hr />- Encourages open discussions, enhancing culture and reducing isolated communications.

52.title: Vietnam Invoice
52.description: The processs of taking Vietnam invoice
52.spr_content: - Ensure invoice date increments with invoice number.<hr />- Include company name, tax code, and address from business registration.<hr />- Verify item details match contract specifications.<hr />- Include the contract number on the invoice.<hr />- Format VAT fields with slashes ("/").<hr />- Sign each sheet individually without overlapping signatures.<hr />- Clearly mark each signature.<hr />- Update and mark new address on the invoice.<hr />- Send completed invoice to the customer.<hr /><hr />For error invoices:<hr />- Revoke any erroneous invoices.<hr />- Clamp three sheets of the invoice together.

53.title: Project Handover
53.description: The checklist shows the process of project handover
53.spr_content: - Create detailed diagrams.<hr />- Ensure source code meets standards.<hr />- Pass all tests before handover.<hr />- Supply HOW-TO guides for development process.<hr />- Enable new member to compile, run, test, and deploy code.<hr />- Conduct a code walkthrough.<hr />- Allow new member to write and deploy code to QA independently (bugfix or small feature).<hr />- Provide access to information on design/implementation decisions.<hr />- Conduct at least 1 hour of pair programming (old with new member).<hr />- Schedule weekly code review sessions.

54.title: Project Communication
54.description: The checklist shows the rule of communication in a project
54.spr_content: - Transparency in email communication aligns with established guidelines.<hr />- Discuss common knowledge work topics in public/shared channels.<hr />- If private discussions occur unintentionally, update relevant team members promptly.<hr />- Maintain professionalism: messages must be polite and appropriate.<hr />- Avoid NSFW content in work conversations.<hr />- Be responsive; don’t ignore messages—signal for follow-up if needed.<hr />- Include relevant individuals in discussions requiring their input.<hr />- Refrain from swearing; uphold respectful language.<hr />- Avoid irrelevant babble in discussions outside personal responsibility.

55.title: Project Archive
55.description: The checklist shows how the project will be archive
55.spr_content: 1. Project title: Archive.<hr />2. Objective: Centralize artifacts in Google Drive.<hr />3. Deliverable: Write a case study reflecting the experience.<hr />4. Communication: Express gratitude and request referrals.<hr />5. Maintenance: Update the audience database for future outreach.

56.title: Project Initialization
56.description: The checklist shows the process of project initialization
56.spr_content: - **Paperwork**: <hr />  - NDA, contingent on client needs.<hr />  - Legally signed agreements via HelloSign for e-contracts.<hr />  - Store all related documents on Drive.<hr /><hr />- **Process**: <hr />  - Ensure resources are prepared and ready.<hr />  - Obtain deposit post-agreement signing, variability based on terms.<hr />  - Establish communication channels.<hr />  - Set up task and project management tools.<hr />  - Schedule project meetings.<hr />  - Clarify project requirements.<hr />  - Initiate and configure the project.

57.title: Unemployment, Social, Health Insurance
57.description: The checklist of unemployment, social, health insurance
57.spr_content: - Employee request for social insurance and contract noted.<hr />- Salary adjustment to be recorded.<hr />- Notice to be sent to Quang and Han regarding salary adjustment.<hr />- Required documentation includes:<hr />  - Social Insurance number.<hr />  - Personal Income Tax (PIT) number.<hr />  - Household Registration Book.<hr />  - ID card (photograph required).<hr />  - Number of inhabitants (photograph required).<hr />  - Declaration of Temporary Residence.<hr />  - Labour Contract.

58.title: Assets
58.description: This checklist is for administrators and employee to manage company's assets.
58.spr_content: - **Lending Process for Admin**<hr />  - Collect asset requests via Basecamp at Woodland in To-dos.<hr />  - Verify the status of requested assets.<hr />  - Log borrower information in Airtable.<hr />  - Establish deadline for asset return.<hr /><hr />- **Collecting Assets for Admin**<hr />  - Retrieve assets from borrowers.<hr />  - Confirm asset status upon collection.<hr />  - Document any damage incurred.<hr />  - Mark To-dos ticket as complete.<hr /><hr />- **Borrowing Process for Employee**<hr />  - Submit requests on Basecamp at Woodland in To-dos.<hr />  - Obtain assets from Admin/Ops Associate.<hr />  - Report any asset damage.<hr />  - Set a return deadline.<hr /><hr />- **Returning Assets for Employee**<hr />  - Check asset status before returning.<hr />  - Report any damages observed.<hr />  - Communicate with Admin/Ops Associate regarding the return.

59.title: Back up Artifact
59.description: To make sure that project’s progress is aligned with the team plan, we collect artifacts every 3 months and save as record of what was done.
59.spr_content: ### Importance of Artifacts<hr />- Artifacts track project progress, facilitating management and control.<hr />- They serve as a learning resource for future teams, detailing past decisions, challenges, and solutions.<hr />- Artifacts enable smooth handovers, onboarding, and traceability when needed.<hr /><hr />### Artifacts Checklist (Quarterly Updates)<hr />- Backup all source codes: Establish a pull process if applicable.<hr />  <hr />#### Project Charter<hr />- Define project purpose and problem-solving focus.<hr />- Outline project scope and team involvement.<hr />- Specify technology stack utilized.<hr />- Identify stakeholders and their roles.<hr />- Detail resource allocation by role.<hr />- Schedule and define purpose for meetings.<hr />- Specify communication channels.<hr />- Maintain a changelog linking to team updates.<hr /><hr />#### Milestones/Roadmap<hr />- Outline team objectives for the next 3 months.<hr /><hr />#### Documentation<hr />- **High-Level Diagrams**: ERD or class diagrams, container diagrams, component diagrams, infrastructure diagrams with function descriptions.<hr />- **Flow/Activity/State Machine Diagrams**: For core or complex features.<hr />- **README**: Include project description, installation and running instructions, and contribution guidelines (coding conventions, source structure, architecture).<hr />- **`.env` Document**: Environmental configurations required.<hr />- **Potential Issues/Roadblocks**: Identify and document challenges faced.

60.title: Hiring
60.description: The checklist presents how the hiring is proceeded.
60.spr_content: - **Resume Collecting**: Identify necessary materials and sources. Utilize job description, job sites, and hiring channels. Implement hiring system in Notion.  <hr />- **Timeline Management**: Schedule invitations and calendar for interviews, assign interviewers. Report results post-interview rounds. Ensure responsiveness and adherence to processes. Monitor potential skips in rounds or missed applicants. Maintain deadlines. Ensure thorough grading of assignments, check for conflicts of interest.  <hr />- **Application Process**: Establish deadlines for applications, interviews, confirmation emails, onboarding, and probation periods.  <hr />- **Offering Strategy**: Act swiftly if a candidate is a good fit. Clearly outline offer packages to avoid vagueness. Stay friendly with candidates who decline offers for potential future opportunities. Confirm completeness of offer information (salary, benefits, etc.). Involve relevant stakeholders (department heads, accounting, operations) in the offer process.  <hr />- **Materials Preparation**: Compile essential resources such as handbooks, pre-assignment tests, assignments, and scenario templates.

61.title: Leave Request
61.description: The checklist of leave and request for the team.
61.spr_content: - Manage leave requests effectively for smooth project operations.<hr />- Acknowledge, discuss, and verify employee leave requests.<hr />- Align workload and resources; reassign critical tasks if needed.<hr />- Plan to cover responsibilities during employee absences.<hr />- Upon Basecamp ticket notification, proceed with approval/denial process:<hr />  - If approved: <hr />    - Mark ticket done, note return date.<hr />    - Notify involved parties; update Google Calendar and inform client.<hr />    - Update project timeline; monitor progress during leave.<hr />  - If denied: <hr />    - Document reason, provide feedback, suggest alternatives.<hr />- 1-2 weeks before holidays: <hr />  - Announce holiday via email to clients.<hr />  - Confirm ongoing projects have holiday plans.<hr />  - Communicate holiday schedule to team on Discord.<hr />- 2-3 days before holidays: <hr />  - Remind clients informally via Slack.<hr />  - Review holiday plans with team for last-minute issues.<hr />  - Reinforce holiday schedule on Discord reminder.

62.title: Candidate
62.description: The checklist will show how to evaluate a candidate.
62.spr_content: - Background qualifications: Logic, English proficiency, specialized technical knowledge.<hr />- Personal attributes influencing hiring:<hr />  - Action-oriented (Doer)<hr />  - Inquisitive (Curiosity)<hr />  - Analytical (Problem-solving)<hr />  - Adaptive (Learner)<hr />  - Cooperative (Teamwork)<hr />  - Receptive (Open-minded)<hr />  - Collaborative spirit<hr />  - Supportive demeanor<hr />- Consideration of past issues in employment history.<hr />- Potential for personality assessment through social channels.

63.title: Consulting Contract
63.description: The checklist presents the process of contract evaluation.
63.spr_content: - Contracts must be incrementally numbered by year.<hr />- Contracts require paging for organization.<hr />- Sufficient contractor information is essential in contracts.<hr />- Payment terms must be numbered with concise descriptions.<hr />- Currency, country, and applicable law (Clause 18) must be updated.<hr />- Termination terms require careful review and consideration.<hr />- Features list or scope of work must be clearly specified, including versioned design and requirement documents.<hr />  <hr />- Contracts must be legally signed by responsible parties (e.g., via hellosign.com).<hr />- Signing contracts is mandatory prior to project initiation.<hr />- Final signed contracts must be stored in the Official Drive folder.<hr />- All contract materials must be saved in Drive, including final PDFs and source files (Word/Google Docs/Pages).

64.title: Billing
64.description: This checklist illustrates the process of billing approval.
64.spr_content: - **Invoice Process Overview**: Defined roles for invoice oversight; primary PIC is Account Lead, secondary is Project Salesperson (e.g., Nam for Attrace).<hr />  <hr />- **Invoice Generation**: Monthly automatic invoice draft generation by Fortress based on previous month.<hr /><hr />- **Client Interaction**: PIC sends Off-days report (25th-27th month) for client confirmation; checks invoice for accuracy (including time-off).<hr /><hr />- **Invoice Submission**: Post client feedback, PIC sends official invoice, status changes to "Sent".<hr /><hr />- **Payment Tracking**: Upon payment receipt, Han updates status to "Paid". If unpaid 7 days post-sending, status becomes "Overdue"; PIC must follow up.<hr /><hr />- **Error Management**: If errors arise post-sending, invoices marked "Error"; PIC communicates issues and issues new invoice.<hr /><hr />- **Compliance Checks**: Ensure accuracy in item pricing, dates, clear descriptions, and pertinent notes in invoices.<hr /><hr />- **Invoice Status Maintenance**: Must reflect current situation, updated by PIC.<hr /><hr />- **Sending Protocols**:<hr />  - Designated PIC sends invoices.<hr />  - Notify clients of errors promptly; mark error in Fortress.<hr />  - Follow up on overdue invoices within 3 days.<hr />  - Confirm payment receipt to clients post-deposit.<hr />  - Send invoices timely (monthly date or after payment milestone).

65.title: Project Case Study
65.description: The checklist outline the criteria of a project case study article
65.spr_content: - Case Study Focus: Client-centric and audience-oriented content.<hr />- Non-Tech Client:<hr />  - Highlight capability to deliver.<hr />  - Clearly reflect problem, solution, and value proposition aligned with Dwarves.<hr />  - Showcase familiar personas from previous clients.<hr />  - Include demonstration of final delivery outcome.<hr /><hr />- Tech Manager & Potential New Hire:<hr />  - Emphasize technical challenge faced.<hr />  - Present detailed system and architecture designs.<hr />  - Convey innovation and technical prowess. <hr /><hr />- Overall Goal: Engage both non-technical and technical audiences by balancing delivery capabilities with complex technical insights.

66.title: Offboarding
66.description: The process when an employee offboard from the team.
66.spr_content: - **Objectives**: Ensure employee satisfaction, minimize disruption, ensure compliance.<hr />- **Project Offboarding**: Confirm last day, resource replacement, complete handoff, back up source code.<hr />- **Exit Interviews and Communications**: Conduct exit interview, gather feedback, invite to alumni events, discuss contractor agreement, inform about final paycheck, send offboarding email, express gratitude.<hr />- **Account and Access Management**: Remove access to email, Git, 1Password, Basecamp, other work channels, databases; update profiles and roles.<hr />- **Equipment and Resources**: Retrieve company assets (laptop, phone), instruct employee to delete code from personal devices.<hr />- **Post-Departure**: Follow up on pending tasks, conduct team meeting for transition, update documentation and contacts.<hr />- **Handover Transfer**: Schedule sessions for knowledge transfer, document unique contributions, capture ongoing research details.<hr />- **Goal**: Facilitate positive exit, maintain relationships, protect company interests, adaptable checklist.

67.title: Make Remote Working Works
67.description: Being office-present keeps you effective. Firms lean on that. It explains why companies are down to invest a fortune on building creative office with other benefit packages. There's nothing wrong about that. I'm just saying there are others ways to keep people.
67.spr_content: - Office presence boosts effectiveness; companies invest in creative environments.<hr />- Alternative engagement methods exist without high operational costs.<hr />- Dwarves prioritize autonomy in work management; meetings focus on decisions, not discussions.<hr />- Covid-19 outbreak prompted minimal changes; remote tools adopted since inception.<hr />- **Self-Preparation:** Timely awareness for meetings avoids crises; readiness matters.<hr />- **Time Management:** Flexibility can lead to unproductive days; self-discipline is key.<hr />- Pomodoro technique enhances focus: 25 minutes work, short breaks, long recovery break after cycles.<hr />- **Work Environment:** Personalize workspace; engage colleagues through shared experiences (e.g., "Snapshot of your Home Desk" campaign).<hr />- **Job Responsibility:** Tackle tasks independently; seek advice only after exhausting options.<hr />- **Documentation:** Essential in remote settings to compensate for limited non-verbal cues; thorough notes are vital.

68.title: Delegation And Believe It Will Work
68.description: We can't always make things (or everything) on our own. If that somehow truly happens, then Inc, Corp, Enterprise or Group won't stand a chance with Freelancers. So why delegating?
68.spr_content: - Collaboration over isolation: No one can do everything alone; leveraging others is key to success.<hr />- Delegation benefits: Reduces stress, provides diverse insights, and frees up time for leaders.<hr />- Essential preconditions for effective delegation: Finding the right skill sets and expertise aligns with job needs.<hr />- Delegation strategy: Guide less experienced delegates with best practices and resources.<hr />- Acceptance of imperfection: Expect outcomes to be 'good enough' rather than perfect; completion is more valuable than perfection.<hr />- Leadership's burden: Decision-making delays arise from excessive risk consideration.<hr />- Clear communication: Outline expectations, deadlines, and address potential pitfalls. Engage in ongoing dialogue and provide constructive feedback.<hr />- Avoiding micromanagement: Empower delegates; frequent check-ins hinder productivity and creativity.<hr />- Responsibility remains: Delegation does not absolve accountability; outcomes trace back to the delegator.<hr />- Competency and development: Trustworthiness and willingness to grow are crucial for effective delegation.<hr />- Delegation as a growth opportunity: View tasks as challenges for the delegate, fostering collaboration and compassion beyond expectations.

69.title: Transparency
69.description: The essence of transparency within a company
69.spr_content: - Initial interviews gauge knowledge about the company; deeper insights come post-hiring.<hr />- Work immersion often leads to isolation from broader company dynamics.<hr />- Information transparency fosters clarity in company operations—embracing both successes and challenges.<hr />- Continuous sharing and feedback through Automatic Check-Ins enhance idea validation and alignment with team goals.<hr />- Openly sharing personal and professional endeavors fosters a culture of collective growth.<hr />- Cross-department communication mitigates potential roadblocks and enhances collaboration.<hr />- Celebrating accomplishments cultivates a culture of achievement without fostering arrogance.<hr />- Transparency builds trust in management and encourages honest communication among team members.<hr />- Effective communication enables understanding of decision-making processes within the company.<hr />- Creating an inclusive atmosphere where all voices are heard enhances engagement and commitment to the company vision.

70.title: Naming convention
70.description: This is the guide how to name your Email, Basecamp, Slack, Trello username.
70.spr_content: - Email format: <first_name><last_name_alias>@d.foundation <hr />- Exception for Operations: <first_name>@d.foundation <hr />- Google Profile: must include GitHub ID or name: <first_name> <last_name><hr />- Basecamp: <hr />  - Photo: face picture<hr />  - Name: <first_name> <last_name><hr />  - Title: Title at Dwarves Foundation<hr />- Slack:<hr />  - Avatar: face picture preferred<hr />  - Full name: Your full Vietnamese name (e.g., Tiêu Quang Huy)<hr />  - Display name: Use GitHub ID for developers; otherwise, use <first_name> <last_name><hr />  - What I do: Your role @ Dwarves Foundation<hr />- Trello/Jira and other tools:<hr />  - Avatar: face picture recommended<hr />  - Name/Nickname: use GitHub name or <first_name> <last_name>

71.title: Project Delivery Schedule and Guidelines
71.description: Dwarves Foundation Team's guide on our project delivery process. This post will serve as your go-to resource for understanding our weekly, bi-weekly, and monthly activities, ensuring that we stay on track and excel in our deliveries as well as handle feedback.
71.spr_content: - **Weekly Points/Effort Report**<hr />  - **Frequency**: Every Friday.<hr />  - **Task**: Fill out report.<hr />  - **Resource**: [Weekly Report Spreadsheet](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1KXUVyDrC9199Dp6wpT6ovIkIvZRtf455eaqwZmvTAFU/edit#gid=0).<hr />  - **Data Sync Deadline**: End of Day next Tuesday.<hr />  - **Result**: Weekly leaderboard based on delivery performance.<hr /><hr />- **Sync-Up Meeting**<hr />  - **Schedule**: Every Friday at 2:30 PM.<hr />  - **Discussion Points**: Project health, milestone progress, weekly changelog.<hr />  - **Output**: Changelog circulated the following Monday.<hr /><hr />- **Bi-Weekly and Monthly Activities**<hr />  - **Project Demo/Showcase**<hr />    - **Timing**: Every 3rd Wednesday.<hr />    - **Attendees**: Consulting and Labs team.<hr />    - **Objectives**: Project updates, market insights, celebration of wins.<hr />    - **Follow-Up**: Recap sent out the following week, featured in monthly community call.<hr /><hr />  - **Community Call**<hr />    - **Occurrence**: Last Friday of the Month.<hr />    - **Agenda**: Delivery Monthly Report, Demo Recap, Monthly Delivery Leaderboard.<hr />    - **Incentives**: ICY rewards and NFT badges for achievements.<hr /><hr />- **Client Feedback**<hr />  - **Frequency**: Every 3 or 6 months, on the Monday of the 1st week of the month.<hr />  - **Responsibility**: Delivery team or Project Leader.<hr />  - **Tool**: [Feedback Form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLScVkRDy9w5_j_Tkj2MXs2Yi_n8yTUqNNBqy8w1-E3Beauodsw/viewform).<hr />  - **Goal**: Collect metrics for effectiveness, improvement suggestions, leadership performance feedback.<hr /><hr />- **Important Reminders**<hr />  - **Weekly Report**: Due every Friday; refer to [[Estimation Guidelines]] for assistance.<hr />  - **Project Recognition**: Notify Consulting team of significant achievements for potential inclusion in demos.

72.title: MBTI Type ISTJ
72.description: All about the ISTJ personality type
72.spr_content: - **Work Environment Preferences**: Favor clear norms; culture is performance-driven; value tangibility over conceptual ideas; appreciate defined responsibilities and planning; avoid risks without substantial facts.<hr /><hr />- **ISTJ Career Satisfaction**: Thrive in roles utilizing technical skills with tangible outputs; adhere to rules and regulations; seek long-term security; prefer stable environments; require hierarchical structure; limit risk-taking; appreciate independent work and timely completion; desire potential for advancement.<hr /><hr />- **Career Exploration Approach**: Conduct thorough research; assess options logically; incorporate personal values into decisions; avoid hasty choices; explore unfamiliar avenues intentionally.<hr /><hr />- **Job Search Behavior**: Investigate various fields thoroughly; accept duration of the search; rely on strong personal connections for networking; prepare documentation carefully; highlight achievements; adhere to deadlines; follow up with gratitude.<hr /><hr />- **Interview Dynamics**: Use evidence to present knowledge; may appear reserved; must demonstrate enthusiasm proactively.<hr /><hr />- **Work Characteristics**: Hardworking and organized; set and achieve tangible goals; adhere to procedures; prefer predictability; comfortable in teamwork but excel independently; avoid unnecessary risks; require minimal supervision.<hr /><hr />- **Awareness in Work**: Challenge adapting to change; resist untested ideas; may focus on daily routines rather than future opportunities; struggle with delegating; could become critical if unappreciated.<hr /><hr />- **Team Collaboration**: Complete assigned tasks diligently; thrive with clear individual roles; favor logical solutions; dislike personal conflicts; share little personal information.<hr /><hr />- **Teamwork Awareness**: May be perceived as picky; need to improve rapport with teammates; may become frustrated with non-cooperative members; should work on timely feedback and maintain positivity.<hr /><hr />- **Leadership Style**: Seek leadership roles; focus on fairness and consistency; base decisions on factual knowledge; adopt traditional leadership approaches; reward rule-followers and task completers.<hr /><hr />- **Communication Style**: Communicate clearly and directly; simplify complex information; prioritize organized and factual dialogue; listen effectively; provide structured feedback.<hr /><hr />- **Communication Improvement Areas**: Share personal viewpoints; build connections; recognize others’ feelings; show appreciation for accomplishments.<hr /><hr />- **Decision Making Approach**: Employ logical and sensible reasoning; gather facts objectively; consider impacts; weigh options against personal values; may need to slow down for comprehensive evaluation.<hr /><hr />- **Stress Triggers**: Overwhelmed by inadequate performance of others; disrupt routine unfavorably; struggle with broad information; feel rushed; have to make irrational changes.<hr /><hr />- **Stress Responses**: Heightened detail orientation; rely on past experiences for solutions; may become overwhelmed or catastrophize; can act impulsively under stress.<hr /><hr />- **Stress Reduction Advice**: Prepare for worst-case scenarios; keep perspective on stressors; focus on future significance; try uncharacteristic actions to gain new insights.

76.title: Thank you letter

90.title: Interview Invitation
90.description: The email template is to annouce the interview date with the client.
90.spr_content: - Title: Interview Invitation from Dwarves Foundation  <hr />- Recipient: [**name**]  <hr />- Purpose: Confirm interview schedule for [**position**]  <hr />- Duration: 60 minutes  <hr />- Date & Time: DD/MM/YYYY - HH:MM AM/PM  <hr />- Location: Floor 18, Block Iris 3, Ha Do Centrosa, 118 3/2 street, District 10, HCMC  <hr />- Parking: Basement bike parking  <hr />- Directions: Use elevator to 1st floor, contact HR Van at 0979291600  <hr />- Requirement: Bring laptop for quick assignment  <hr />- Contact: Hotline 0282 246 0 246  <hr />- Closing: Questions welcome, anticipation of the interview  <hr />- Sign-off: Best regards, Dwarves Foundation

91.title: National Day
91.description: The email template that you need to send to client when it's near holiday to announce about the absence.
91.spr_content: - Dwarves Foundation: Express gratitude.<hr />- Vietnam National Day: Commemorates independence (September 2, 1945).<hr />- Public holiday regulation (2019): Closure schedule communicated.<hr />- Foundation closed: [**date**] to [**date**].<hr />- Normal business resumes: [**date**].<hr />- Queries/orders: Submit 3 days to 1 week prior to holiday.<hr />- Post-holiday processing for late requests.<hr />- Contact for emergencies: (+84) 282 246 0246.<hr />- Apologies for inconvenience.<hr />- Appreciation for understanding.

92.title: Red Flags
92.description: These red flags are things we don’t want to see in our peeps. Even when you think they are improper, don’t waste your time with a wrong group of people.
92.spr_content: - **Negative Attitude**: Exhibits disengagement, lack of motivation, integrity issues, resistance to learning.<hr />- **Incompatibility**: Misalignment with company culture; personality clashes with team members.<hr />- **Lack of Professionalism**: Shows unprofessional behaviors, such as tardiness, absenteeism, missed deadlines, poor communication.<hr />- **Poor Performance**: Fails to meet performance standards; struggles with task completion.<hr />- **Low Morale**: Contributes to decreased team morale; potentially toxic environment.<hr />- **High Turnover Rate**: Indicates possible poor hiring decisions; employee frequently leaves.

93.title: The OKR
93.description: How we use OKR to define goals
93.spr_content: - OKR: Management methodology; outcome-driven tracking framework.<hr />- Components:<hr />  - Object: goal to achieve.<hr />  - Key Results: measurable indicators of progress towards the objective.<hr />- Example:<hr />  - Objective: Build a strong backend team.<hr />  - Key Results: <hr />    - Hire 2 senior backend developers.<hr />    - Organize 1 training session per week.<hr />- OKR structure:<hr />  - Foundation level: company-wide objectives and key results.<hr />  - Team level: specific objectives for team actions.<hr />  - Individual level: personal objectives for team members.<hr />- Keys to OKR:<hr />  - Set quarterly and annually.<hr />  - Ensure key results are measurable with specific metrics.<hr />  - Utilize both top-down (company) and bottom-up (individual) approaches.<hr />  - Share all OKRs company-wide for transparency.<hr />  - Grade key results on a scale from 0 to 1 for progress tracking.<hr />  - Limit to maximum 5 objectives and 4 key results each quarter.<hr />- Benefits over KPIs:<hr />  - Increase clarity in objective alignment across all levels.<hr />  - Enhance focus on achieving the right results.<hr />  - Foster collaboration through shared objectives and accountability.<hr />- Application process:<hr />  1. Conduct brainstorming session for quarter objectives.<hr />  2. Communicate company-wide objectives.<hr />  3. Draft personal OKRs.<hr />- Utilization tool: Hygger Board for organizing and tracking OKRs.<hr />- Suggested readings for further understanding:<hr />  - Articles and video resources on OKR success and implementation.

94.title: The Dwarves Culture Handbook
94.description: For the past 5 years, we didn't have something called 'Culture Book'. Whenever a newbie steps in, it's natural to pick up the job and go with the flow. We hardly force them into other periodical office traps like team-bonding activities or late night drinks.
94.spr_content: - Absence of 'Culture Book' for past five years creates a flow-oriented work environment.  <hr />- Newbies adapt organically; no mandatory bonding activities.  <hr />- Informal celebrations: birthdays often lead to unexpected treat requests, showcasing camaraderie.  <hr />- Workplace lacks the idealized charm of nurturing and friendly interactions typically associated with other establishments.  <hr />- Employees may seek 'friendlier' environments outside the current culture when disillusioned.  <hr />- Engaging conversations are encouraged in key comfortable spaces: kitchen, sofa, balcony.  <hr />- Discord channels serve as a platform for casual interaction, especially for less socially inclined individuals.  <hr />- Reading the Dwarves Culture Handbook provides insight into organizational spirit and values.  <hr />- Handbook encapsulates beliefs and future aspirations of Dwarves Foundation, shaped by collective daily experiences.  <hr />- Key principles of the culture are craftsmanship, teamwork, and sustainability.  <hr />- The handbook evolves like software; welcomes contributions for ongoing improvement.  <hr />- Share and instill these values with new team members to enrich the culture.  <hr />- Continual adaptation and growth is essential for all members.

95.title: The Inner Circle
95.description: The concept of an "inner circle" within a company is not a new one, and at Dwarves, a software company founded by a group of engineers, this idea holds a significant value.
95.spr_content: - "Inner circle" concept prevalent in organizations, particularly at Dwarves.<hr />- Dwarves: software company founded by engineers focused on efficiency. <hr />- Value placed on individuals who efficiently ship software. <hr />- Respect and status within the company tied to contributions to shipping processes. <hr />- Differentiation between effective contributors and hindrances is clear. <hr />- Inner circle formed by respect, recognition, not status or past achievements.<hr />- Inclusion in inner circle based on consistent demonstration of value.<hr />- Impact on company's success is the primary criterion for inner circle membership.<hr />- Structure reflects broader organizational dynamics beyond Dwarves. <hr />- Efficiency and contribution are foundational to company success narratives.

96.title: Types Of Employees
96.description: Employees are either job-focused or mission-driven "mitochondria" who drive company growth. Prioritizing the latter through values interviews is key to startup success.
96.spr_content: - Two employee types exist: job-focused and mission-driven.  <hr />- Job-focused employees see work as transactional, valuing fair compensation and projects.  <hr />- Their contributions scale linearly; they are rational actors in the workplace.  <hr />- Mission-driven employees embody company values, passionate about the mission.  <hr />- They transcend job descriptions, adding exponential value to the company.  <hr />- They energize teams and are essential in startup growth stages.  <hr />- This group is akin to mitochondria, powering and sustaining organizational health.  <hr />- Early-stage startups rely on these individuals as core components; they evolve into leadership.  <hr />- Cherishing and cultivating them is critical for sustainable growth.  <hr />- Invest in relationships, maintaining awareness of this group's thoughts and sentiments.  <hr />- Conduct values interviews to align candidates with company culture and core values.  <hr />- Founders or existing mission-driven employees should conduct these interviews.  <hr />- Not interviewing for values results in suboptimal hiring, losing potential mission-driven talent.

97.title: Our Metrics For Performance Review
97.description: Performance is a final value that will be calculated from other metrics. This value will help to indicate how good all the activities we've done to make the company could grow.
97.spr_content: 1. **Performance (P)**: Calculated value reflecting company growth efforts; rated 1 (bad) to 5 (outstanding).<hr />   <hr />2. **Result (R)**: Measures output effectiveness; evaluated by project manager/team leader based on punctuality, workload, and quality.<hr /><hr />3. **Metrics**:<hr />   - **Punctuality**: Efficiency in timely task completion; assessed via logged hours/points.<hr />   - **Workload**: Level of effort contributed to the project.<hr />   - **Quality**: Work standard; driven by engagement and recognition of achievements.<hr /><hr />4. **Example Calculation**: Integrating punctuality, workload, and quality factors into performance score. Coefficients determine weighting.<hr /><hr />5. **Teamwork (T)**: Evaluates collaborative conduct; essential for success.<hr />   - **Proactivity**: Initiate actions without dependencies; approachability during work hours.<hr />   - **Cooperation**: Assist and share knowledge.<hr /><hr />6. **Firing Protocol**:<hr />   - **False Positives**: Hire who seem fit but do not align post-hire; fire quickly.<hr />   - **False Negatives**: Dismiss those not deemed fit but may excel; consider hiring them.<hr /><hr />7. **Performance Assessment**:<hr />   - **Incompetent Assholes**: Low performance; immediate termination.<hr />   - **Competent Assholes**: High performance with value misalignment; remediate or separate.<hr />   - **Incompetent Nice Guys**: Low performance, high culture fit; manage/training required.<hr />   - **Competent & Nice**: High performance and cultural fit; deserving of praise and advancement.<hr /><hr />8. **Dark Triad**: Key behavioral traits affecting team dynamics - psychopathy, machiavellianism, narcissism; breed manipulative actions for varying personal gains.<hr /><hr />9. **Startup Dynamics**:<hr />   - Focus: Solving real problems and contributing socially.<hr />   - Team Vision: A shared purpose guiding all actions; contributors over employees.<hr />   - Coordination: Essential for team efficiency; synchronization trumps individual skills.<hr /><hr />10. **Communication Metrics**:<hr />    - Daily transparency, effective presentations, clear writing, appropriate meeting engagement, resourceful problem-solving.<hr />    - **Helpfulness**: Fostering teamwork by supporting colleagues.<hr />    - **Leadership**: Initiating new ideas and guiding teammates.<hr /><hr />11. **Contribution (C)**:<hr />    - Encompasses broader external and cultural impacts; community engagement and innovation.<hr />    - Assessments include culture-building, forward-thinking, and technological adeptness.<hr /><hr />12. **Ranking (R)**: Focus on career development and growth metrics within the company scope. <hr /><hr />13. **Team Philosophy**: Emphasizes unity, strength in collaboration, and shared achievements while recognizing individualities.

98.title: MBTI Type ESTJ
98.description: All about the ESTJ personality type
98.spr_content: - ESTJ characteristics: thorough analysis, practical planning, process control, and responsibility.<hr />- Prefers structured, performance-driven environments with clear norms.<hr />- Values facts, details, and tangible products/services over concepts.<hr />- Desires clarity in roles, rules, and expectations; dislikes ambiguity and risk-taking.<hr />- Finds satisfaction in organized, high-stakes environments involving task/resource management.<hr />- Conducts detailed career exploration through facts, networking, logical evaluation, and values alignment.<hr />- Organizes effective job searches; balances job requirements with personal capabilities.<hr />- In interviews, highlights competencies with examples; needs to build connections without being overly dominant.<hr />- At work, ESTJs are dependable, decisive, detail-oriented, and aim for efficiency.<hr />- Support organizational structures and policies; prefer established methods for problem-solving.<hr />- Must be aware of potential inflexibility and the impact of their high standards on others.<hr />- On teams, they contribute energy, challenge peers, and expect commitment and efficiency.<hr />- Leaders organize plans for results, provide clear expectations, and encourage adherence to policies.<hr />- Communicate directly, favor logical discussions over small talk; may need to soften critiques.<hr />- Make decisions based on objective evaluation, past experiences, and consideration of impacts on others.<hr />- Experience stress when facing inefficiency, uncertainty, or perceived lack of control.<hr />- Stress responses may include withdrawal, emotional outbursts, rigidity, or work obsession.<hr />- Stress management strategies: talk about feelings, reassess goals, spend time alone, and reflect on situations.

99.title: Collaboration Guidelines
99.description: Guidelines for project collaboration between Dwarves and our Clients.
99.spr_content: - **Tools Overview**: Utilize Basecamp for project management and communication, Jira for sprint planning and tracking, Google Meet for meetings, and Github/Gitlab for source control; design with Figma/Sketch.<hr />- **Schedule**: Kick-off meeting (1 session), weekly or bi-weekly sprints, planning and review meetings each sprint, daily standups via communication channels.<hr />- **Meeting Notes**: Send within 30 minutes post Sprint planning and retrospective meetings.<hr />- **Project Management**:<hr />  - All members involved in Sprint planning.<hr />  - Milestones and features listed on Jira/Basecamp at kick-off.<hr />  - New requests go to Icebox/Backlog; bugs handled based on priority.<hr />  - Aim for “Potentially Shippable” software each Sprint.<hr />- **Design & Development**: <hr />  - Design team delivers UI elements (color palette, fonts, base components) before the start of each Sprint.<hr />- **Backend & Frontend Coordination**:<hr />  - Establish API documentation and environments; agree on naming conventions early.<hr />- **Quality Assurance**:<hr />  - Document bugs with specifics; utilize dedicated testing environments for frontend.<hr />- **Release Schedule**: Releases occur at Sprint end; hotfixes are ad-hoc, including semantic version tagging and release notes.<hr />- **Customer Feedback**: Direct feedback to respective team leads based on nature (Development, Sprint results, Pricing).<hr />- **Issues Management**:<hr />  - Four severity levels dictate response and resolution times, from critical (<30 mins) to minor (1 business day).<hr />- **Billing Process**: Invoices sent monthly; based on deployed resources and project type (Fixed-price or T&M), with necessary payment details provided.<hr />- **Payment Terms**: Clients have 10 business days to pay, penalties for late payments without prior written approval.<hr />- **Project Team Responsibilities**:<hr />  - **Team Lead**: Infrastructure and technical oversight, progress reporting.<hr />  - **Account Manager**: Client feedback management and relationship maintenance.<hr />  - **Project Manager**: Project standards implementation, deliverable production, risk management, and reporting.

100.title: MBTI Type ISTP
100.description: All about the ISTP personality type
100.spr_content: ### ISTP Work Environment and Career Insights  <hr /><hr />**Work Environment Preferences:**<hr />- Practical, skill mastery; tangible results.<hr />- Variety; transition in and out of activities.<hr />- Disregard for rules aids effective emergency responses.  <hr /><hr />**Career Satisfaction Characteristics:**<hr />- Technical application in practical settings.<hr />- Skill mastery for specific tasks.<hr />- Hands-on work; tool usage.<hr />- Clear project guidelines for concrete outcomes.<hr />- Collaboration with respected, competent individuals.<hr />- Opportunities for problem-solving and crisis management.<hr />- Independent work with minimal supervision.<hr />- Challenging, enjoyable tasks with little oversight.  <hr /><hr />**Career Exploration Behavior:**<hr />- Compile specific career facts; focus on current and predictive opportunities.<hr />- Take time to assess options; uncertainty about choices.  <hr /><hr />**Job Search Dynamics:**<hr />- Collect job-related info; organize structured job search plans.<hr />- Extra effort required; convey experience through documentation.<hr />- Risk-taking; adapting to new job possibilities, networking selectively.  <hr /> <hr />**Interview Behavior:**<hr />- Quiet, reserved demeanor; straightforward responses.<hr />- Practice discussing skills; cautious about detail and future scenarios.  <hr /><hr />**Workplace Traits:**<hr />- Concentration on interesting projects; organized information.<hr />- Attraction to tangible products; focus on active task completion.<hr />- Preference for solo work; mutual respect for competent colleagues.<hr />- Potential rule-breaking for efficiency; minimize unnecessary discussions.<hr />- Flexibility in workload responses; calm under pressure.  <hr /><hr />**Awareness Needs at Work:**<hr />- Additional planning time needed; anticipate future possibilities.<hr />- Risk of being easily distracted by new projects; patience for task completion; might appear disorganized.<hr />- Boredom with routine; benefit from improved organization.<hr />- Focus on immediate solutions; inclination for spontaneity may appear irresponsible.  <hr /> <hr />**Team Dynamics:**<hr />- Provide necessary data; organize and analyze efficiently.<hr />- Logical conflict resolution; motivate teammates; fair treatment.  <hr /><hr />**Potential Team Challenges:**<hr />- Avoidance of interpersonal conflicts; irritation from focus on specifics.<hr />- Frustration with overly emotional teammates; need for appreciation and rapport-building.  <hr /><hr />**Leadership Style:**<hr />- Quiet, example-setting approach; freedom from rigid policies.<hr />- Information compilation to persuade; logical decision-making; expect equal contributions.  <hr /><hr />**Communication Style:**<hr />- Preference for logical, objective information; minimal unnecessary communication.<hr />- Reliance on non-verbal cues; dislike of superficiality.  <hr /><hr />**Communication Awareness Needs:**<hr />- Intentional sharing of thoughts; comfort in emotional expression.<hr />- Consideration for others’ feelings; active listening and feedback provision.  <hr /><hr />**Decision-Making Approach:**<hr />- Decisions based on tangible data; rational evaluation of options.<hr />- Examination of broader implications; integration of personal values.  <hr /><hr />**Stress Triggers:**<hr />- Emotion control issues; strict guidelines; perceived incompetence of others.<hr />- Illogical situations; overwhelmed by tasks; excessive sociability.<hr />- Emotional co-worker interactions.  <hr /><hr />**Stress Response:**<hr />- Heightened focus on logic; resistance to help.<hr />- Sensitivity to others' perceptions; feelings of alienation.<hr />- Potential emotional outbursts under extreme stress.  <hr /><hr />**Stress Reduction Strategies:**<hr />- Analyze facts for clarity; engage in independent, divertive activities.<hr />- Focus on personal values; reenergize through solitude.<hr />- Disregard others' perceptions.

101.title: The Four Preferences
101.description: The four preferences in MBTI personalities
101.spr_content: 1. **Extraversion vs. Introversion**: Distinction between external engagement (extraverting) and internal reflection (introverting). <hr />   - Extraverting activities: talking, listening, cooking, working on cars.<hr />   - Introverting activities: reading, contemplating, self-awareness, problem-solving.<hr />   - Preference influences life's direction and source of energy.<hr /><hr />2. **Sensing vs. Intuition**: Differences in information gathering methods.<hr />   - Sensing: concrete data absorption via senses (tasting, observing changes, memorizing, following plans).<hr />   - Intuition: abstract possibilities and meanings from gathered data (innovation, future implications, perceiving underlying meanings).<hr />   - Preference affects trust in information gathering.<hr /><hr />3. **Thinking vs. Feeling**: Two criteria for decision-making.<hr />   - Thinking: logic and reason-focused decisions (research products, fairness, adherence to rules).<hr />   - Feeling: subjective, value-based decisions (personal liking, emotional considerations, environmental preferences).<hr />   - Balance between both leads to easier decisions; conflict brings dominant preference to the fore.<hr /><hr />4. **Judging vs. Perceiving**: Attitude towards the external environment and day-to-day living.<hr />   - Judging: preference for order, closure, and planning (to-do lists, scheduling, forming judgments).<hr />   - Perceiving: preference for flexibility and spontaneity (postponing decisions, spontaneous actions, last-minute tasks).<hr />   - Differences can create challenges in relationships; complementary dynamics possible in mixed preference partnerships.

102.title: Go The Extra Mile
102.description: A couple days ago, I was asked if I were ever a product person, what would I do to make the best out of it. It took me a while. I mean, I've never walked in this shoe before. Wth is a product person? I wondered. And I started digging. Here it is, "Making sure your product/ thing shipped out flawlessly." A perfectionist mindset.
102.spr_content: - A product person ensures flawless product delivery. <hr />- Requires a perfectionist mindset; intriguing yet challenging. <hr />- Quality is paramount; no one wants poor products. <hr />- Poor creations lead to dissatisfaction; the goal is to create excellence. <hr />- Exceed expectations; a commitment to constant improvement is crucial. <hr />- Regularly evaluate and optimize previous work for growth. <hr />- Attention to detail is essential; little things shape the overall quality. <hr />- A polished product reflects strong work ethic and self-regard. <hr />- The principle "How you treat yourself is how others will treat you" applies to products as well. <hr />- The extra mile stems from genuine passion, not overwork. <hr />- True commitment elevates the quality of a product. <hr />- Focus on quality over quantity; one well-crafted product is better than multiple subpar ones.

103.title: Constructive Feedback
103.description: It's in human nature to instantly lose their mind when things get hard, and somehow they split nasty things that can't be undone. So, to reduce the ratio of unnecessary conflicts, let's make the feedback great again.
