easy upgrades enhance performance and security.<hr /><hr />- **Strengths vs Java**:<hr />  - **Small to Medium Services**: Fast load times, efficient resources, suitable for quick development.<hr />  - **Cloud-Native Applications**: Minimal cold start time; enhanced performance for serverless architecture.<hr />  - **Concurrent Programming**: Goroutines provide lightweight concurrency handling, outperforming Java's green threads.<hr /><hr />- **Positioning**: Viable enterprise language but unlikely to replace Java; Java's ecosystem supports extensive applications (Android, data processing, complexity).<hr />- **Usage Spectrum**: Both languages have strengths; cooperation can build high-performance, reliable applications.

151.title: How to use Go in the Enterprise
151.description: This content map explores strategies and best practices for implementing Go as a primary programming language in enterprise environments. It covers Go's strengths in scalability, concurrency, and performance, as well as addressing common challenges and considerations for large-scale adoption in corporate settings.
151.spr_content: - Go's applicability in enterprise environments is increasing.<hr />- Resources: <hr />  - Uber's style guide for Go promotes best practices.<hr />  - Reddit discussions highlight user experiences and challenges with Go in enterprise applications.<hr />  - MobiDev emphasizes Go's benefits for scalable application development.<hr />- Key advantages of Go:<hr />  - Efficient concurrency model for high performance.<hr />  - Robust standard library facilitating rapid development.<hr />  - Strong typing system improving code reliability.<hr />- Examples of use cases:<hr />  - PID controllers in robotics, showcasing practical applications.<hr />  - High-performance data processing, illustrated by handling 1.5 million PDFs efficiently.<hr />- Performance optimization tools like PGO (Profile Guided Optimization) enhance CPU efficiency.<hr />- Emphasis on adopting best practices ensures maintainability and scalability in large systems.

152.title: Why Enterprise Chose Java
152.description: Java has been widely adopted as the primary programming language for enterprise-level software development, emphasizing its platform independence, robust ecosystem, and extensive libraries. This choice aims to enhance scalability, ensure long-term support, and leverage Java's strong object-oriented programming principles in large-scale enterprise applications.
152.spr_content: - Java originated from Sun Microsystems' Oak, aimed at embedded systems, renamed for trademark reasons.<hr />- Popularity surged after being released for free; Sun marketed Java as industry-standard to secure revenue.<hr />- Java’s "write once, run anywhere" feature solved platform incompatibility for diverse enterprise environments.<hr />- Introduction of Java EE provided essential tools for developing complex, enterprise-grade applications.<hr />- Java supports synchronous/asynchronous messaging, integrating with XML, JSON, and Protobuf for seamless communication.<hr />- Extensive libraries and frameworks (e.g., JSP, Servlets, Spring) essential for robust web applications.<hr />- High-quality drivers offered for both relational and NoSQL databases enrich Java’s database interaction capabilities.<hr />- Java prioritizes memory safety, reducing risks associated with manual memory management seen in C/C++.<hr />- Facilitates user access management via integrations with protocols like LDAP, SAML, and OAuth.<hr />- A large developer talent pool simplifies hiring and community support enhances problem-solving.<hr />- Java’s platform independence allows deployment across varied operating systems and cloud services, providing flexibility.<hr />- Java's support for APM tools aids in maintaining application health and performance.<hr />- Rich ecosystem of libraries, frameworks, and IDEs accelerates development and boosts productivity.<hr />- C/C++ is faster but Java's ease of use, memory safety, platform independence, and adequate speed outweigh speed considerations. <hr />- Java's gradual popularity rise in enterprises stems from its adaptability and comprehensive feature set.

153.title: Who is using Go in enterprise?
153.description: This content map explores the companies and organizations that have embraced Go as their primary programming language for enterprise-level applications.
153.spr_content: - **Technology Giants:**<hr />  - Google: Created Go in 2007, used for internal tools/services like Kubernetes, Docker.<hr />  - Meta (Facebook): Uses Go for the Ent schema as code tool.<hr /><hr />- **Cloud Providers:**<hr />  - Amazon Web Services (AWS): Utilizes Go for services including AWS Lambda.<hr />  - DigitalOcean: Developed doctl, a command-line tool for API interaction.<hr /><hr />- **Financial Services:**<hr />  - American Express: Adopted Go for backend services.<hr />  - Zerodha: Employs Go for their trading platform.<hr /><hr />- **Media and Entertainment:**<hr />  - Netflix: Created Rend, a memcached-compatible server and proxy.<hr />  - Twitch: Utilizes Go for video streaming infrastructure.<hr /><hr />- **Ride-sharing and Delivery:**<hr />  - Uber: Provides a Go style guide for developers.<hr />  - Einride: Implements Go for a microservices architecture.<hr /><hr />- **Cybersecurity:**<hr />  - Cloudflare: Extensively uses Go in edge computing platforms/services.<hr /><hr />- **Productivity Tools:**<hr />  - Dropbox: Rewrote core components in Go to enhance performance.

154.title: When to use Go in the Enterprise
154.description: This section explores the scenarios and considerations for adopting Go as a programming language in enterprise environments. It discusses the advantages of Go's simplicity, efficiency, and concurrency support, as well as its suitability for building scalable and maintainable enterprise applications.
154.spr_content: - Go is suited for enterprise applications that require high performance and scalability.<hr />- It offers simplicity and ease of learning, promoting rapid development.<hr />- Concurrency features enable efficient handling of multiple tasks simultaneously.<hr />- Strong standard library supports various functionalities out-of-the-box.<hr />- Go's static typing helps catch errors early in the development process, enhancing reliability.<hr />- The lightweight nature of Go binaries simplifies deployment and maintenance.<hr />- Go supports microservices architecture, making it ideal for distributed systems.<hr />- Growing community and ecosystem provide robust tools and libraries.<hr />- Suitable for cloud-native applications due to its compatibility with containerization.<hr />- Go's garbage collection reduces memory management complexity for developers.

155.title: Go Commentary #12: CLI Renaissance with Kubernetes, REST, and Terminal Readers in the Age of Complexity
155.description: A critical examination of Go's resurgence in CLI tool development, exploring recent projects in Kubernetes log viewing, REST API interaction, and terminal-based readers, while questioning the industry's shift back to command-line interfaces.
155.spr_content: - **kl**: Interactive Kubernetes log viewer for terminal.<hr />- **Functionality**: Views logs across multiple containers, pods, clusters.<hr />- **Analogy**: Like `kubectl logs` enhanced—raises question of why not part of `kubectl`.<hr />- **Critique**: Fragmentation in Kubernetes ecosystem; new tools solving non-existent problems.<hr /><hr />- **Restish**: CLI tool for REST-ish HTTP API interaction.<hr />- **Features**: Automatic API discovery, command generation.<hr />- **Example**: Converts standard HTTP requests automatically.<hr />- **Reflection**: Does it truly solve problems or just adds abstraction layers?<hr />- **Irony**: CLI for machine-to-machine communication designed for simplicity.<hr /><hr />- **cast-text**: Fast full-text news reader for terminal, handles RSS.<hr />- **Trend**: Shift towards terminal tools; nostalgia for simplicity of text interfaces.<hr />- **Reflection**: Rejection of rich web experiences in favor of monospaced text.<hr />- **Complexity**: New CLI tools often complex, shifting rather than simplifying complexities. <hr /><hr />- **Theme**: Pendulum swing in software design between interfaces; complexity remains.

156.title: Go Commentary #9: TinyGo, SQLite Vector Search, and Authorization
156.description: Exploring TinyGo's latest release, a new vector search extension for SQLite, and an open-source authorization service inspired by Google Zanzibar.
156.spr_content: ### TinyGo 0.33.0<hr />- Go compiler optimized for microcontrollers, WebAssembly, command-line tools.<hr />- Integrates Go libraries with LLVM for Go program compilation.<hr />- Added support for Go 1.23, including range-over-func feature.<hr /><hr />### sqlite-vec<hr />- Minimal, efficient vector search extension for SQLite.<hr />- Supports float, int8, binary vector storage and querying via virtual tables.<hr />- Pure C implementation, no dependencies, runs on various platforms including Linux, MacOS, Windows, and in browser with WASM.<hr />- Allows pre-filtering of vectors using subqueries.<hr /><hr />### Permify 1.0<hr />- Open-source authorization service inspired by Google Zanzibar.<hr />- Centralizes and standardizes authorization logic, detached from application code.<hr />- Supports granular permissions using domain-specific language (DSL) compatible with RBAC, ReBAC, ABAC.<hr />- Enables default settings for tenant authorization with isolated management.<hr />- Optimized for rapid access checks, achieving response times as low as 10ms.

157.title: Go Commentary #4: Ethical Hacking, HTTP Requests, Mac App Development
157.description: This post explores two cutting-edge applications of Go programming. First, it details an ethical hacking project that successfully sent 500 million HTTP requests to 2.5 million hosts using Go's concurrency features and custom optimizations. The article then introduces DarwinKit, a powerful Go library for creating native Mac applications without Objective-C or Swift. Both examples demonstrate Go's versatility in handling high-performance networking tasks and cross-platform development, showcasing its potential for complex, scalable projects in cybersecurity and application development.
157.spr_content: ### Sparse Priming Representation<hr /><hr />**Title: Scaling Concurrent HTTP Requests & Mac App Development with Go**<hr /><hr />---<hr /><hr />**Sending HTTP Requests:**<hr /><hr />- **Objective:** Ethical hacking, efficiently send 500 million HTTP requests to 2.5 million hosts within a few hours.<hr />- **Language Choice:** Go, favored for concurrency and speed despite initial exploration in Rust.<hr />  <hr />**Challenges:**<hr /><hr />- Single-threaded `curl` execution → 7.9 years for 500 million requests.<hr />- Data transfer:<hr />  - 500 million requests ≈ 478 GB<hr />  - 500 million responses ≈ 2.33 TB<hr />- HTTP request breakdown:<hr />  1. DNS resolution<hr />  2. TCP connection<hr />  3. TLS handshake<hr />  4. HTTP request preparation<hr />  5. Await response<hr />  6. Parse response<hr />  7. Close connection<hr />- Slow DNS resolution (~160 ms) and connection setup hinders performance.<hr />- Distribution across numerous hosts → prone to rate limiting or bans.<hr /><hr />**Solution:**<hr /><hr />- Distributing workload via multiple servers.<hr />- Streamlining processes:<hr />  - Pre-resolved DNS with massdns.<hr />  - Bypass request parsing by crafting raw HTTP requests.<hr />  <hr />**Implementation Strategy:**<hr /><hr />1. **Worker Pools:**<hr />   - Request generation pool<hr />   - Sender pool<hr />   - Response pool<hr />2. **Concurrency-safe queue** to manage tasks and optimize memory use.<hr />3. **Fast HTTP Client:** Chose `fasthttp` for x10 speed improvement, bypassing normalization.<hr />4. **Dialer Override:** Custom function to handle pre-resolved IP addresses.<hr />5. **TLS Optimizations:** Potential key hardcoding to save CPU cycles.<hr />6. **Chunking hosts:** Operate in groups of 200 to balance speed and minimize connection overhead.<hr />7. **Infrastructure:** Deployed on DigitalOcean K8s for scalable resource management, avoiding blocking from Cloudflare.<hr /><hr />**Results:**<hr /><hr />- Each pod achieved 100-400 requests/second.<hr />- Scaled deployment to 60 pods, accomplishing the target of 500 million requests within hours.<hr /><hr />---<hr /><hr />**Building Mac Apps with Go:**<hr /><hr />- **Context:** Lack of native Mac API bindings for Go led to creation of DarwinKit.<hr />- **Features of DarwinKit:**<hr />  - Covers 33 frameworks, 2,353 classes, 23,822 properties/methods.<hr />  - Supports block arguments as Go functions.<hr />  - 1-to-1 mapping with Objective-C symbols, idiomatic Go style.<hr />  - Comprehensive documentation available for Apple APIs.<hr />  <hr />**Future Roadmap:**<hr /><hr />- Generating bindings for Apple API framework functions.<hr />- Aim to eliminate CGO in favor of `purego`.<hr />- Enhanced efficiency, smaller binaries, and broader application compatibility.<hr />- Contributions welcomed, expanding bindings primarily for MacOS for now.<hr /><hr />--- <hr /><hr />**References:**<hr />- [500 Million HTTP Requests Guide](https://www.moczadlo.com/2024/how-i-sent-500-million-http-requests-in-under-24h)<hr />- [Building Mac Apps with Go](https://dev.to/progrium/how-i-build-simple-mac-apps-using-go-104j)<hr />- [DarwinKit on GitHub](https://github.com/progrium/darwinkit)

158.title: Go Commentary #3: Generic Collections, Generics Constraints, AI Bot
158.description: Implementing generic collections in Go: challenges and solutions, with examples of sortable sets and constraints. Updates on Go's generics support and insights on a new AI bot being developed for the Go community. Stay current with Go's evolving ecosystem and best practices for using generics effectively.
158.spr_content: - Generics in Go introduced in version 1.18, underutilized.<hr />- Poor documentation on writing generic collections.<hr />- Goal: Create a sortable set (slice/map) for any type.<hr />- Example implementation of `Sortable` interface for `Name` struct to define ordering:<hr />  ```go<hr />  type Sortable[T comparable] interface { Less(member T) bool }<hr />  ```<hr />- Attempted to create `SortableSet` but faced issues with type instantiation.<hr />- Built-in slices provide partial solutions, but direct application to maps fails due to type constraints.<hr />- Solution proposed involves using interfaces to create a `SortableConstraint` for better type control:<hr />  ```go<hr />  type SortableConstraint[T comparable] interface { comparable; Sortable[T] }<hr />  type SortableSet[T SortableConstraint[T]] interface { Add(member T); Size() int; Contains(member T) bool; Sorted() []T }<hr />  ```<hr />- Effective implementations for `SliceSet` and `MapSet` now feasible.<hr />- Current resources (Google research, official docs) are insufficient; article provides practical insights.<hr />- Cheatsheet for type constraints aids understanding of generics behavior.<hr />  <hr />- Development of AI tool (`Gaby`) underway to assist automation in Go projects.<hr />- Gaby aims to evaluate the utility of LLMs in the context of coding practices.<hr />- Engagement with the community encouraged through feedback on bot interactions.

159.title: Go Commentary #17: Leveraging benchstat Projects in Go benchmark and Go Plan9 memo on 450% speeding up calculations
159.description: Understanding benchstat usage in Go benchmark and Go Plan9 on boosting up performance
159.spr_content: - **Benchmarking in Go**: Essential for measuring performance and optimizations.<hr />  - **Old-school Approach**: A/B comparisons using `benchstat`.<hr />    - Steps: <hr />      1. Create benchmark function.<hr />      2. Run benchmarks for versions A and B.<hr />      3. Analyze results with `benchstat`.<hr />    - Example: Compare different protocol versions for efficiency (e.g., Remote Write 1.0 vs. 2.0).<hr />  - **Limitations of Old-school**:<hr />    - Tracking changes is difficult; optimizations may go unnoticed.<hr />    - Accidental changes to benchmark code can mislead results.<hr />    - Collaboration and replication are challenging in larger projects.<hr /><hr />- **New-school Approach**: Comprehensive benchmarking with multiple cases.<hr />  - Single command for running all cases, facilitating broader comparisons.<hr />  - Example: Benchmark across various sample sizes, compression methods, and protobuf encoders.<hr />  - Rewritten `benchstat` supports advanced filtering and reporting.<hr />  <hr />- **Limitations of New-school**:<hr />  - Increased complexity and longer run times for benchmarks.<hr />  - Harder to iterate and clear visibility on what is being benchmarked.<hr />  - Not practical for committing expansive benchmarks in production; better suited for remote branches.<hr /><hr />- **Conclusion**: <hr />  - Hybrid approach recommended.<hr />  - Use tools like `-format csv` for exporting and visualizing data.<hr /><hr />- **SIMD in Go**: Leveraging concurrency beyond standard capabilities.<hr />  - SIMD: A technique for optimized operations in data processing.<hr />  - **Plan9 Assembly**: Tailored for specific architectures (e.g., amd64).<hr />    - Example: Simple assembly routine for integer addition with go.<hr />      - Unique syntax and operational flow in assembly as compared to Go.<hr /><hr />- **Performance Gains**: Significant speed enhancements (up to 450%) observed using Plan9.<hr />  - Current support: Primarily x86 architecture, with future potential for arm architecture.

160.title: Go Commentary #15: Using Go embed, and Reflect
160.description: Quick notes on Go embed and Go Reflect
160.spr_content: - **Go Embed Directive**: `//go:embed` includes files/folders in binary at compile time.<hr />- **Memory Access**: Enables direct application access to resources from memory, bypassing disk I/O.<hr />- **Single File Example**: <hr />  - Embed `message.txt` with content "hello from bytesizego!"<hr />  - Code imports `embed` package, defines `var message string`, prints content.<hr />- **Multiple Files Example**: <hr />  - Embed all `.txt` files from `messages` directory into `var messages embed.FS`.<hr />  - Iterates through files, reads each, and prints filename and content.<hr />- **Directory Example**: <hr />  - Embed entire `static` directory.<hr />  - Reads `static/index.html`, prints its content.<hr />- **Limitations**:<hr />  - **Binary Size**: Large files increase compiled binary size significantly.<hr />  - **File Changes**: Changes require recompilation for updates.<hr />  <hr />- **Go Reflection Context**: <hr />  - Reflect on structures using `reflect` package to obtain field types and methods.<hr />- **Laws of Reflection**:<hr />  - **Interface to Object**: Converts between interface values and reflection objects.<hr />  - **Settable Requirement**: For modifications, reflection object must be settable.<hr />- **Zeroth Law Warning**: Use reflection cautiously; misuse leads to panics without error recovery.

161.title: Go Commentary #24: Coming in Go 1.24: testing/synctest experiment for time and concurrency testing
161.description: Go 1.24 testing/synctest experiment for time and concurrency testing
161.spr_content: - **Context of Testing**: Go tests often rely on time, which can be unreliable due to system clock variations. <hr />- **Traditional Approach Flaws**: <hr />  - Uses time.Sleep and measures elapsed time.<hr />  - Can pass or fail inconsistently depending on the operating system's clock.<hr />- **Introduction of `testing/synctest`**:<hr />  - Aims for more deterministic outcomes in time and concurrency testing in Go.<hr />  - Usage requires import of the package and `gotip` with environment variable `GOEXPERIMENT=synctest`.<hr />- **Concurrency Challenges**:<hr />  - Tests using goroutines may introduce flakiness due to timing issues.<hr />  - Example of a concurrent test is shared, which counts ticks using a Ticker.<hr />- **Solution with `synctest`**:<hr />  - Wrapping tests with `synctest.Run` mitigates timing issues, leading to more reliable results.<hr />- **Implications and Recommendations**:<hr />  - Anticipates significant improvements in testing reliability for code that manipulates time or concurrency.<hr />  - Encourages experimentation with the new package before its formal release in Go 1.24.<hr />- **Call to Action**: Directs readers to engage with the main proposal and report their findings. <hr />- **Links for Further Exploration**: Includes resources for additional reading on the proposal and experiments.

162.title: Go Commentary #18: Fuzz Testing Go HTTP Services
162.description: Understanding how to use Fuzz Testing in Go
162.spr_content: - In programming, not all inputs can be anticipated; bugs may go unnoticed unless explicitly sought.<hr />- Fuzz testing in Go introduced with version 1.18 enhances code reliability.<hr />- To create a fuzz test in Go, follow these steps:<hr />  1. Write a function starting with "Fuzz" in a _test.go file using *testing.F.<hr />  2. Utilize f.Add() to input corpus seeds for the fuzzer to generate varied data.<hr />  3. Use f.Fuzz() to invoke the fuzzing process with a target function's arguments.<hr />  4. Execute the fuzzer with the command: `go test --fuzz=Fuzz`.<hr /><hr />- Example of a potential bug in a function:<hr />  - The Equal function may encounter an index out of range panic.<hr /><hr />- Sample fuzz test for the Equal function:<hr />  ```go<hr />  func FuzzEqual(f *testing.F) {<hr />      f.Add([]byte{'f', 'u', 'z', 'z'}, []byte{'t', 'e', 's', 't'})<hr />      f.Fuzz(func(t *testing.T, a []byte, b []byte) {<hr />          Equal(a, b)<hr />      })<hr />  }<hr />  ```<hr /><hr />- Fuzzing an HTTP service with structured requests and responses:<hr />  - Define Request and Response structs to format incoming and outgoing data.<hr />  - ProcessRequest function decodes JSON, handles logic, and sends a formatted JSON response.<hr />  <hr />- Fuzz test for the ProcessRequest function:<hr />  ```go<hr />  func FuzzProcessRequest(f *testing.F) {<hr />      testRequests := []Request{<hr />          {Limit: -10, Offset: -10},<hr />          {Limit: 0, Offset: 0},<hr />          {Limit: 100, Offset: 100},<hr />          {Limit: 200, Offset: 200},<hr />      }<hr />      for _, r := range testRequests {<hr />          if data, err := json.Marshal(r); err == nil {<hr />              f.Add(data)<hr />          }<hr />      }<hr />      // Create server and handle fuzzing logic...<hr />  }<hr />  ```<hr /><hr />- Example of potential runtime errors during fuzz testing:<hr />  - "integer divide by zero" and "slice bounds out of range" are indications of hidden bugs.<hr /><hr />- Conclusion: <hr />  - Fuzz testing reveals latent bugs that traditional tests may miss due to unexpected inputs.

163.title: Go Commentary #23: Draft Release Notes for Go 1.24 and weak pointers in Go
163.description: Draft Release Notes for Go 1.24 and the incoming of weak pointers in Go
163.spr_content: - **Go 1.24 Overview**<hr />  - Not launched; anticipated release in February 2025.<hr />  - Introduces **generic type aliases** allowing parameterization.<hr />    - Example: <hr />      ```go<hr />      type nodeList = []*Node<hr />      ```<hr />  - Feature can be disabled; `GOEXPERIMENT=noaliastypeparams` applicable until Go 1.25.<hr /><hr />- **Tool Enhancements**<hr />  - Updates to `go tool`, inclusion of `-tool` flag.<hr />  - New `tests` analyzer integrated with `go vet`.<hr /><hr />- **Library Improvements**<hr />  - `os.Root` type for directory-specific file operations.<hr />    - Methods: `Open`, `Create`, `OpenFile`, `Mkdir`.<hr />  - Enhancements for `crypto`, `hash`, and `net/http` packages.<hr />    - Support for HTTP/2 protocol settings.<hr />  - Revamped `sync.Map` for better performance and resolution of longstanding issues.<hr /><hr />- **Weak Pointers in Go**<hr />  - **Definition**: Reference type that allows garbage collection of the referenced object.<hr />    - Example of `weak` package defines safe use of weak pointers:<hr />      ```go<hr />      type Pointer[T any] struct { u unsafe.Pointer }<hr />      ```<hr />  - Weak pointers become `nil` when their references are garbage collected, preventing memory access issues.<hr />  <hr />- **Usage Scenario**<hr />  - Ideal for **canonicalization maps** to maintain unique data presence.<hr />    - Example: <hr />      ```go<hr />      fmt.Println("h1 == h2:", h1 == h2)  // Identical references.<hr />      ```<hr /><hr />- **Operational Mechanism**<hr />  - Utilizes an intermediate object for efficient garbage collection.<hr />  - Collector modifies the indirection object pointer, allowing batch cleanup of weak references.

164.title: Go Commentary #14: Golang compile-time evaluation and Go bindings to SQLite using wazero
164.description: A quick toolings for compile-time evaluation and SQLite wrapper with WebAssembly runtime for Go
164.spr_content: - **Golang Comptime**: A tool for compile-time function evaluation in Go, akin to Zig's `comptime`.<hr />- **Functionality**: <hr />  - Evaluate functions at build time, yielding computed results instead of runtime calculations.<hr />  - Integrate as a Go library or standalone executable.<hr />  - Compatible with Go build via `-toolexec`.<hr />- **Example Code**: Demonstrates using `prep.Comptime` to compute Fibonacci number during compilation.<hr />- **Usage**: Command to build includes `-toolexec="prep <path>"`.<hr />- **Limitations**:<hr />  - Supports only basic literals as arguments.<hr />  - Requires functions to be fully resolvable with provided literals; no I/O values allowed.<hr /><hr />- **go-sqlite3**: Go bindings for SQLite using a WebAssembly runtime.<hr />- **Features**:<hr />  - Cgo-free SQLite wrapper ensuring compatibility with `database/sql`.<hr />  - Direct access to SQLite's C API.<hr />  - Utilizes `wazero` for executing the Wasm build of SQLite.<hr />- **Dependencies**: Requires Go, `wazero`, and `x/sys`.<hr />- **Example Code**: Opens a SQLite database and retrieves the SQLite version.<hr />- **Links**: <hr />  - [prep GitHub](https://github.com/pijng/prep)<hr />  - [go-sqlite3 GitHub](https://github.com/ncruces/go-sqlite3)<hr />  - [wazero GitHub](https://github.com/tetratelabs/wazero)

165.title: Go Commentary #20: Go Turns 15
165.description: The 15th anniversary of the Go open source release
165.spr_content: - Go programming language celebrates 15 years; user base tripled in 5 years.<hr />- Achieved status as a top 10 language and essential for cloud computing.<hr />- Notable updates with Go 1.22:<hr />  - Resolved sharing of loop variables in goroutines.<hr />  - Introduced range support over integers.<hr />  - Performance enhancements: 1-3% CPU gains, 1% memory reduction via runtime optimization.<hr />  - Added profile-guided optimization (PGO) improving static dispatch and efficiency by 2-14%.<hr />  - New **math/rand/v2** package with advanced pseudo-random generation.<hr />  - **net/http.ServeMux** pattern support for methods and wildcards.<hr />  - Introduced *Null[T]* type in **database/sql** for nullable columns.<hr />  - New Concat function in **slices** for concatenating multiple slices.<hr />- Go 1.23 features:<hr />  - Allows for-range loops with user-defined iterator functions.<hr />  - Preview of generic type aliases.<hr />  - Introduction of Go telemetry for toolchain usage insights.<hr />  - Enhanced `go env` and `go mod tidy` commands for better user experience.<hr />  - `go vet` reports on symbols incompatible with target Go versions.<hr />- Future goals for Go:<hr />  - Adapt to modern hardware capabilities with improved map implementations.<hr />  - Prototype new garbage collection methods for contemporary constraints.<hr />  - Develop new APIs and tools tailored for enhanced performance.<hr />  - Collaborate on AI integration (LangChainGo & Genkit).

166.title: Go Commentary #21: Go sync.Once is Simple
166.description: Understanding Go's sync.Once - A Deep Dive into Single-Execution Guarantees and Atomic Operations
166.spr_content: - **sync.Once Overview**: Guarantees one-time execution of an action.<hr />- **Implementation**: <hr />  - `var once sync.Once`<hr />  - Example defining `GetConfig()`: delays config fetching until first access.<hr />- **Usage in Singleton Pattern**: <hr />  - Ensures a single instance of a struct.<hr />  - Example: `GetSingleton()` initializes only once.<hr />- **Performance Benefits**: Enables lazy-loading, enhancing runtime performance and memory efficiency.<hr />- **Panic Handling**: No direct reset; future calls to `Do(f)` can fail silently after a panic.<hr />- **Error Handling**: Modified `GetConfig()` returns config and error.<hr />- **New in Go 1.21**: <hr />  - `OnceFunc`, `OnceValue`, `OnceValues`: Fallbacks for error handling and value caching upon panic.<hr />- **Implementation Details**:<hr />  - Basic structure includes a mutex and a done flag.<hr />  - Original approach locking unconditionally, leading to inefficiency.<hr />- **Optimization**: <hr />  - Revised method checks done flag before locking to reduce contention.<hr />  - Merits of inlining functions enhance overall efficiency.<hr />- **Race Condition Risk**: Previously introduced by flag setting order; resolved with careful defer usage.<hr />- **Inlining Functionality**: Modern Go compilers leverage inlining for optimal performance.<hr />- **Conclusion**: Effective usage of `sync.Once` aids concurrency while maintaining efficiency and simplicity in Go applications.

167.title: Go Commentary #6: GUI Framework, Leadership Change
167.description: Introducing Cogent Core, a new GUI framework for Go, and announcing Russ Cox stepping down as Tech Lead of Go after 12 years.
167.spr_content: - **Cogent Core Framework**: GUI framework in Go, enabling "Code Once, Run Everywhere" across major platforms (macOS, Windows, Linux, iOS, Android, web).  <hr />- **Single Codebase**: Identical application functionality across devices, exemplified in a simple "Hello, World!" app.  <hr />- **Standard Widgets**: Supports typical GUI components (buttons, text fields, sliders, tables) with examples showcasing interactive elements.  <hr />- **Event Handling**: Features callbacks for GUI interaction, like messaging on button clicks and synchronized data binding between UI controls.  <hr />- **Data Visualization**: Integrates interactive plot capabilities for data representation.  <hr />- **Key Features**:  <hr />  - Comprehensive GUI widget set aligned with Material 3 standards.  <hr />  - Built-in tooltips, drag-and-drop, sprites, and a fully-featured text editor.  <hr />  - User-friendly styling options and responsive design for cross-platform compatibility.  <hr />  - Transparent widget implementation for easy customization and dynamic color management.  <hr />- **Ecosystem**: Complete software environment for extensive development support.  <hr />- **Russ Cox Transition**: Former Tech Lead of Go, Russ Cox steps down to focus on Oscar, an AI system for maintaining open-source projects.  <hr />- **Leadership Change**: Austin Clements appointed as new Tech Lead.  <hr />- **Oscar**: An AI agent system designed to support open-source sustainability.

168.title: Go Commentary #7: Releases, Websockets, and Struct Behavior
168.description: Exploring Go 1.23 release notes, the new home for nhooyr/websocket, and common mistakes with Go structs and slices.
168.spr_content: - Go 1.23 Release emphasizes new features; review notes for comprehensive updates.<hr />- nhooyr/websocket library adopted by Coder for Cloud Development Environment (CDE).<hr />- Go structs are copied on assignment; observe the implications in code behavior.<hr />- Example 1: Modifying a copied struct does not affect the original.<hr />- Example 2: Pointer to a struct in a slice incorrectly returns a pointer to a copy.<hr />- Fix: Use index to return a pointer to the original struct from the slice.<hr />- Example 3: Slicing with incorrect capacity may affect underlying array.<hr />- Fix: Specify capacity in slicing to prevent unintentional modifications.<hr />- Important to understand Go's value semantics for efficient programming.

169.title: Go Commentary #19: Writing secure Go code
169.description: Pratices to write secure Go code
169.spr_content: - Security in Go code requires proactive measures and continual knowledge updating.  <hr />- Stay informed about Go security announcements by subscribing to `golang-announce@googlegroups.com`.  <hr />- Keep Go code updated to ensure it receives security patches and maintains compatibility with dependencies.  <hr />- Regularly check Go release notes for security issues and CVEs, update `go.mod` accordingly, and verify compatibility.  <hr />- Testing Go code for security involves tools like `go vet`, `staticcheck`, and `golangci-lint` for static analysis.  <hr />- Use `go test -race` to detect race conditions.  <hr />- Employ `govulncheck` to scan source code and binaries for known vulnerabilities.  <hr />- Use `gosec` for identifying security issues with a focus on common vulnerabilities (e.g., weak random number generators).  <hr />- Integrate fuzzing tests to uncover potential security flaws such as buffer overflows and code injections.  <hr />- Understand CVEs (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) for awareness of prevalent software vulnerabilities.  <hr />- Seek resources like databases and community announcements to stay updated on vulnerabilities and best practices.  <hr />- Fuzzing is critical for uncovering various attack vectors in web services.

170.title: Go Commentary #10: Script, Telemetry
170.description: Exploring a Go library for shell-like scripting and Go's telemetry feature.
170.spr_content: - Go library "script" facilitates writing shell-like scripts. <hr />- Provides a fluent API for file manipulation, text processing, and command execution.<hr />- Key features include:<hr />  - Chainable methods for piping operations.<hr />  - Simplified file and directory operations.<hr />  - Text processing akin to grep and sed.<hr />  - Command execution with streamlined output handling.<hr />  - Integrated error handling within the API.<hr />- Usage examples demonstrate functionality:<hr />  - Reading file contents as a string.<hr />  - Counting matching lines in files.<hr />  - Filtering standard input through custom Go functions.<hr />  - Appending arguments to a specified file.<hr />  - Making simple HTTP requests.<hr />- Go toolchain supports telemetry for usage and error tracking.<hr />- Commands for telemetry management:<hr />  - `go telemetry on` to enable.<hr />  - `go telemetry off` to disable.<hr />  - `go telemetry local` for local-only mode. <hr />- Resources for further reading linked.

171.title: Go Weekly #2: Go 1.23 Iterators
171.description: Exploring the new Go package for iterators - learn what it is, what the controversy is about, and how to use it.
171.spr_content: - Go lacks a standardized iterator for user-defined containers.<hr />- `for` `range` iterates over native types: maps, slices, strings, arrays, channels.<hr />- Existing non-generic iterators: <hr />  - *runtime.CallersFrames* for stack frames.<hr />  - *bufio.Scanner* for `io.Reader`.<hr />  - *database/sql.Rows* for query results.<hr />- Pre-generics, no interface for universal iteration was possible.<hr />- Go 1.22 proposed `iter` package for generic iteration, handling sequences:<hr />  - `Seq[V]` and `Seq2[K, V]` types enable passing elements via a `yield` callback.<hr />- Iterators yield successive elements until a stopping condition is met.<hr />- Introduced examples: `Backward` function demonstrates reversed iteration.<hr />- The complexity in `for range`: <hr />  - `true` implies continuation, `false` implies a break.<hr />- Syntax appears more functional, diverging from traditional imperative style.<hr />- Anticipation exists for community adoption and feedback.

172.title: Go Commentary #5: Features, Memory Optimization, Minecraft Server, Code Editor, and LLM Tool
172.description: Explore Go version features, memory optimization techniques, a Go-powered Minecraft server, a pure Go source code editor, and a tool for running large language models.
172.spr_content: - Go Language:<hr />  - Releases every six months.<hr />  - Major releases supported until two newer major versions are available.<hr />  - Critical issues addressed through minor revisions.<hr /><hr />- BetterAlign Package:<hr />  - Fork of fieldalignment.<hr />  - Enhances memory usage efficiency in structs.<hr />  - Excludes generated files, test files, and ignores specified structs.<hr />  - Preserves comments, though position heuristics are being refined.<hr />  - Reliable atomic file I/O, with caveats on Windows.<hr />  - Rigorous testing of optimizations.<hr />  - Tailored for constrained environments (Docker, K8s).<hr /><hr />- ZeppelinMC:<hr />  - High-performance Go-based server for Minecraft 1.21.<hr /><hr />- Go Code Editor:<hr />  - Pure Go implementation.<hr />  - Features: auto-indentation, file handling, process execution, and plugin support.<hr />  - Golang specific functionalities: integrates goimports, identifier navigation, debugging utility.<hr />  - Language Server Protocol (LSP) for enhanced code analysis and completion.<hr /><hr />- Ollama 0.3:<hr />  - Tool for efficiently running Large Language Models.  <hr /><hr />- Resource Links:<hr />  - Various links provided for further context and access to projects.

173.title: Go Commentary #13: Compiler Quests and Vector Vexations
173.description: A scathing look at Go's compiler internals and the vector search gold rush, exposing the industry's obsession with speed over substance
173.spr_content: - Register allocation in Go's compiler reveals intricacies of low-level performance optimization.<hr />- Interest level varies; akin to knowing asphalt composition for drivers—mostly irrelevant for everyday users.<hr />- Compiler speed focus leads to a "very fast" register allocator occupying 20% of optimization time; efficiency questioned.<hr />- Example code illustrates potential inefficiencies: variable spills incurred due to local register allocation.<hr />- Quick compilation vs. runtime performance trade-off; fast compile times do not guarantee optimal code execution.<hr />- BBQvec represents a surge in vector search technology within AI applications, described as scalable and modern.<hr />- Industry hype for vector search might overshadow understanding and actual necessity, akin to fleeting trends.<hr />- Many startups adopt vector search for appearances rather than genuine need; actual utilization questioned.<hr />- BBQvec claims capabilities for "many billions of vectors"; real demand in this space is debatable.<hr />- Algorithm employs innovative indexing with random orthonormal basis sets and bitmaps, but emphasizes build speed.<hr />- Key concern: focus on indexing speed rather than search accuracy and performance longevity.

174.title: Go Commentary #11: The Gopher's LLM Revolution - Actors, Frameworks, and the Future of Go
174.description: A critical look at Go's evolving role in the LLM ecosystem and the frameworks shaping its future
174.spr_content: - **Go Survey**: Collective feedback from Go developers deemed essential for understanding usage, challenges, desired features, and community support.<hr />  <hr />- **LLMs in Go**: Recognizes the surge in popularity of Large Language Models and their impact on developer perception and technology relevance.<hr /><hr />- **Go's strengths**: Concurrency and networking align with LLM applications' distributed nature; an unexpected yet fitting evolution.<hr /><hr />- **RAG Server Example**: Demonstrates simplicity of Go, contrasting with more complex frameworks in other languages; straightforward, minimalistic design.<hr /><hr />- **LangChainGo**: A new abstraction layer for LLM interactions via simple interfaces. Critiqued as potentially unnecessary complexity.<hr /><hr />- **Genkit**: Google's tool for LLM management, criticized for adding needless complexity to an already convoluted toolkit landscape.<hr /><hr />- **Ergo Framework**: Introduces the actor model to Go, complete with buzzword features claiming to solve obscure problems; criticized for potential overengineering.<hr /><hr />- **Gopher's Dilemma**: Tension between Go's original simplicity and the influx of frameworks promising all-encompassing solutions; essential to focus on real problems.<hr /><hr />- **Future of Go**: Encouragement to maintain pragmatism and clarity amidst new developments. Emphasis on continuing to meet challenges the "Go way".<hr /><hr />- **Software development ethos**: Constantly evolving without losing core values; practical solutions should drive development rather than trends.

175.title: Go Commentary #16: Understand sync.Map
175.description: Understanding sync.Map and using the right tools for atomic operations in Go.
175.spr_content: - **Concurrent access challenges in Go**: Direct map usage results in fatal errors during concurrent read/write operations.<hr />- **sync.Map benefits**: Manages locking automatically; reduces concerns about race conditions.<hr />- **Performance advantages**: Facilitates faster read, write, and delete operations.<hr />- **Key sync.Map methods**:<hr />  - `Store(key, value)`: Adds a key-value pair.<hr />  - `Load(key)`: Retrieves value by key.<hr />  - `Delete(key)`: Removes a key-value pair.<hr />  - `Range(func)`: Iterates over entries; allows concurrent operations without locking down the map.<hr />- **Iterative safety**: Iterating through traditional maps during writes is unsafe; leads to errors.<hr />- **Under-the-hood design**:<hr />  - Contains a readonly map (for fast, lock-free lookups) and a dirty map (for new entries).<hr />  - Uses atomic pointers to enable concurrent access without locks.<hr />- **Data consistency trade-off**: Snapshot during iteration may not reflect the latest updates.<hr />- **Entry states**:<hr />  - **Normal**: Valid entry; data retrievable.<hr />  - **Deleted**: Entry removed but marked as existing; pointer set to nil.<hr />  - **Expunged**: Fully deleted entry; marked with a sentinel value.<hr />- **Optimal scenarios for sync.Map**: Data-read heavy workloads with infrequent writes.

176.title: Go Commentary #22: GoMLX: ML in Go without Python
176.description: Running Machine Learning inference in Go without Python
176.spr_content: - GoMLX enables machine learning in Go without relying on Python.<hr />- ML models traditionally implemented in Python using TensorFlow, JAX, or PyTorch.<hr />- Features of these frameworks include:<hr />  - Expressive model architecture descriptions.<hr />  - Auto-differentiation for training optimization.<hr />  - Efficient computational primitives for CPUs, GPUs, and TPUs.<hr />- High-level primitives convert ML models to StableHLO (High-Level Operations).<hr />- OpenXLA components:<hr />  - XLA compiler: Converts HLO to hardware machine code.<hr />  - PJRT: Manages hardware resources, handles tensor data movement, execution, and sharding.<hr />- GoMLX wraps the XLA system, offering access to TensorFlow and JAX building blocks.<hr />- Example of a CNN model (C10ConvModel) illustrated using Go:<hr />  - Explicit structure with convolution, activation, dropout, and dense layers.<hr />  - Incorporates specific tensor shape assertions throughout the model.<hr />- Classifier example demonstrates image classification with tensor manipulation in Go.<hr />- Alternative example illustrates text generation using a pretrained Kaggle model (Gemma2).<hr />- Conclusion: GoMLX offers an innovative, albeit experimental, approach to ML inference via Go.<hr />- Potential challenges: Newness of the project might pose risks for production deployment.

177.title: Go Commentary #8: Jupyter Notebooks, Kubernetes Tools, GopherCon Talks
177.description: Explore GoNB for Jupyter notebooks, kubetrim for KUBECONFIG management, and key highlights from GopherCon UK 2024 talks, covering performance testing, software design, event-driven workflows, and AI's impact on tech jobs.
177.spr_content: - **GoNB**: Jupyter kernel for Go. <hr />  - Features: auto-complete, contextual help.<hr />  - Rich content: supports HTML, markdown (LaTeX), images, JavaScript, SVG, videos.<hr />  - Interactive widgets: sliders, buttons via HTML.<hr />  - Plotly and ECharts integration: enhanced data visualization capabilities.<hr />  <hr />- **kubetrim**: CLI tool for automatic KUBECONFIG management.<hr />  - Checks and updates connections to Kubernetes clusters.<hr />  - Reports connection status with success or failure messages.<hr /><hr />- **GopherCon UK 2024 Talks Highlights**:<hr />  1. **Performance Testing Tools**: Tool for replaying HTTP access logs to test system performance during low traffic.<hr />  2. **Software Design Complexity**: Emphasizes management of design complexity, specifically in API interactions.<hr />  3. **Event-Driven Workflows**: Discussion on building technology-agnostic libraries utilizing different technologies (Kafka, Redux, etc.).<hr />  4. **AI's Impact on Work**: Exploration of how AI affects future job landscapes in tech, encouraging relevance amidst automation. <hr /><hr />- **References**:<hr />  - GoNB Repository: [GitHub](https://github.com/janpfeifer/gonb)<hr />  - ECharts Integrations: [go-echarts](https://github.com/go-echarts/go-echarts), [gonb-echarts](https://github.com/janpfeifer/gonb-echarts)<hr />  - kubetrim Repository: [GitHub](https://github.com/alexellis/kubetrim)<hr />  - GopherCon Talks Playlist: [YouTube](https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLDWZ5uzn69ezR6D6FUj_iBSOyRc9xaZFP&si=IdFGYzOivQqFRsVb)

178.title: Go Weekly #1: Mastering Go Performance - eBPF and PGO Optimization Techniques
178.description: Explore advanced Go optimization techniques using eBPF for kernel-level insights and Profile-Guided Optimization (PGO) for compiler enhancements. Learn how to boost performance and efficiency in Go applications.
178.spr_content: - Software development typically occurs in user space (applications, utilities, etc.), away from the kernel of the OS.<hr />- Profiling from user space is unreliable due to overhead affecting CPU/memory.<hr />- Kernel source code modifications are impractical for minor use cases, slow adoption in distributions.<hr />- Writing kernel modules requires ongoing maintenance and poses risks of system crashes due to bugs.<hr />- BPF (Berkeley Packet Filter) originated for filtering network packets.<hr />- eBPF (Extended BPF) enables tracing syscalls, user space functions, and network packets for monitoring and security.<hr />- eBPF operates through predefined hooks in the kernel, is event-driven, verified for safety, and executes code pre-system calls.<hr />- eBPF serves diverse use cases: systems programming, observability, and security.<hr />- Profiling can utilize existing tools like Parca, Pyroscope, or PGO from Go 1.20 for ease of implementation.<hr />- Profile-Guided Optimization (PGO) in Go 1.20, also known as Feedback-Directed Optimization (FDO), gathers profile data for optimized builds.<hr />- PGO can improve performance by 2-14% from the second build onward.<hr />- Grab's experimentation with PGO on TalariaDB resulted in significant resource savings (10% CPU, 30% memory, 38% volume).<hr />- PGO's effectiveness is less substantial (5% reduction) on orchestrated services.<hr />- Monorepo services face challenges due to dependency on pprof processes for PGO compatibility.<hr />- PGO is best suited for low-effort, simply deployed services.

179.title: Go import design: using git repo path
179.description: Go’s use of git repository paths as package identifiers is a unique and powerful feature. Unlike most languages that rely on centralized package repositories, Go links directly to git paths.
179.spr_content: - Go's import system is integrated with git repositories, enhancing developer experience.<hr />- Each package has a unique identity via git paths, preventing namespace conflicts.<hr />- Example import statement: `import "github.com/username/projectname/package"`.<hr />- Eliminates the need for complex dependency tools; promotes clean codebases.<hr />- **Global uniqueness**: Git paths ensure unique identifiers, especially for large projects.<hr />- **Direct version control**: Developers can pin dependencies to specific git tags or commits for reproducible builds.<hr />- Universal access: Any git repository (public/private) can source Go packages, minimizing reliance on third-party registries.<hr />- **Modularity & reusability**: Git paths encourage self-contained packages, simplifying maintenance and code inspection.<hr />- Other languages (Python, Java, Ruby) primarily use centralized registries, leading to naming conflicts.<hr />- Go's git-based identifiers link directly to package sources, avoiding centralized naming issues.<hr />- Example `go.mod` structure: <hr />  ```<hr />  module myproject<hr />  go 1.20<hr />  require (<hr />      github.com/user/mathlib v1.3.0<hr />      github.com/otheruser/utils v0.9.2<hr />  )<hr />  ```<hr />- Go's evolution from `$GOPATH` to modules shows the shift in its dependency management strategy.<hr />- Initial design included multiple workspaces with independent versions of dependencies.<hr />- `$GOPATH` set the current workspace, containing source code and build artifacts.<hr />- Workspaces allowed for vendored dependencies, analogous to Python's virtual environments.<hr />- Original version expected dependency updates to be compatible; lacked automatic version tracking.<hr />- The transition to Go Modules in 2019 standardized dependency management, addressing earlier limitations.
