This market report isn't exhaustive, at least just yet, with certain trends not yet listed such as Blockchain, data management, DevEx, etc. We see a lot of promising trends and we hope that understanding what engineers and firms are becoming more passionate about that it will help us create a foundation of ideas and knowledge.
189.spr_content: - **Frontend Shifts**: React's stagnation prompts simpler frontend solutions; popularity of Multi-Page Applications (MPAs) rises. Concerns over vendor lock-in with Next.js and Vercel.<hr />  <hr />- **HTMX Popularity**: Emerging interest in HTMX for minimizing JavaScript; enhances HTML attributes for dynamic functionality.<hr /><hr />- **Rust Ecosystem Growth**: Rust powers successful projects (e.g., Zed, Mastro); gaining traction in front-end and UI rendering, especially with WebAssembly.<hr /><hr />- **AI-Driven Productivity Tools**: Businesses adopting in-house AI tools for remote work efficiency; integrated software favored over fragmented solutions.<hr /><hr />- **LLMs Evolution**: Mistral's `mistral-medium` shows competitive potential with GPT-4, signaling a shift from OpenAI dominance in language models.<hr /><hr />- **Automation in Trading**: Trading bots automate financial transactions; increasing demand in crypto and traditional markets, with a focus on optimization and copy trading.<hr /><hr />- **Cybersecurity Demand Surge**: Rising cybercrime necessitates updated cybersecurity strategies; Zero Trust model gains prominence in response to skill gaps and ransomware threats.
189.tags: AI LLM cybersecurity frontend htmx labs market-report rust

190.title: Pure CSS Parallax
190.description: This article demonstrates how to use CSS transforms, perspective and some scaling trickery to create a pure CSS parallax scrolling website.
190.spr_content: - **CSS Parallax Scrolling**: Implemented using CSS transforms, perspective, and scaling.<hr />  <hr />- **Advantages of Pure CSS**: <hr />  - Avoids JavaScript complexity and performance hit.<hr />  - Prevents browser rendering issues (reflows/paints).<hr />  - Utilizes hardware acceleration for smooth scrolling.<hr />  - Compatible with responsive design features.<hr /><hr />- **Implementation Structure**:<hr />  - Basic HTML structure includes a parallax container and layers.<hr />  - CSS defines perspective, overflow, and layer positioning.<hr /><hr />- **Key CSS Properties**:<hr />  - `perspective`: Establishes a fixed 3D viewpoint.<hr />  - `overflow-y: auto`: Enables vertical scrolling; descendant layers align in 3D.<hr />  - `translateZ`: Controls layer positioning relative to the viewport depth.<hr /><hr />- **Layer Dynamics**: <hr />  - Closer layers move faster relative to movement; farther layers appear slower.<hr />  - Use multiple sections for varied effects.<hr /><hr />- **Grouping Layers**:<hr />  - Requires a wrapper `group` element.<hr />  - Must avoid `overflow: hidden` to maintain parallax behavior.<hr />  - `transform-style: preserve-3d`: Ensures 3D positioning retention.<hr /><hr />- **Depth Correction**:<hr />  - Use `scale` transform to maintain apparent size disparities.<hr />  - Scale calculation: `scale = 1 + (translateZ * -1) / perspective`.<hr /><hr />- **Debugging Strategies**:<hr />  - Adjust `transform` properties to visualize layer positions (e.g., using `translate3d`).<hr /><hr />- **CodePen Links**: Interactive examples for practical implementation and testing.

191.title: CSS Container Queries
191.description: Container Queries is a CSS feature that allows us to style elements based on the size of a container.
191.spr_content: - Container Queries introduced in Chrome 105 on August 30, 2022.<hr />- Media Queries adjust styles based on viewport size, limiting responsive component design.<hr />- Container Queries enable styling based on the size of a parent container, enhancing responsive components.<hr />- Use `container-type` property with values: `size`, `inline-size`, `block-size`, `style`, `state`.<hr />- Example: `.sidebar { container-type: inline-size; }`<hr />- Query a container using `@container` to target the nearest containment context.<hr />- Example: `@container (min-width: 300px) { .content { display: none; } }`<hr />- Containers can be named with `container-name`, allowing specific queries.<hr />- Example: `.sidebar { container-type: inline-size; container-name: my-sidebar; }`<hr />- Shorthand syntax: `.sidebar { container: my-sidebar / inline-size; }`<hr />- Specific queries with named containers: `@container my-sidebar (min-width: 300px) { .content { display: none; } }`<hr />- Browser support: Chrome 105+, Safari 15+, Edge 105+, with polyfill for universal support.<hr />- References include MDN, Plain English, Ishadeed, and Chrome DevTools documentation on Container Queries.

192.title: CSS in JS
192.description: CSS-in-JS is a styling technique where Javascript is used to style the component.
192.spr_content: - CSS-in-JS: JavaScript-based component styling.<hr />- Libraries: Emotion, Styled-components, JSS.<hr />- Aims: Overcome CSS limitations (dynamic functionality, scoping, portability).<hr /><hr />**Benefits:**<hr />- Scoping: Isolated styles prevent unintended global effects.<hr />- Unique Selectors: Automatic generation avoids naming collisions.<hr />- Dynamic Styling: JavaScript logic enables complex styles (loops, conditionals).<hr />- Dead Code Elimination: Only active styles loaded; unused styles removed.<hr />- Developer Ergonomics: Co-located styles enhance workflow; reduce intimidation.<hr /><hr />**Disadvantages:**<hr />- Runtime Cost: CSS generation overhead in browsers; build-time extraction mitigates this with trade-offs.<hr />- Learning Curve: New syntax and mindset required; potential temporary slowdown.<hr />- Unreadable Class Names: Automatically generated selectors hinder debugging; efforts to maintain clarity are partial.<hr />- Increased Bundle Size: Additional library can slow page load times.

193.title: MPA, SPA and Partial Hydration
193.description: MPA, SPA and Partial Hydration are three different approaches to building web applications.
193.spr_content: - **Terms Explained**: "Partial Hydration", "MPA" (Multi-Page Application), "SPA" (Single-Page Application).<hr />- **Web Trends**: Shift back to static websites; MPA offers speed and SEO advantages over SPAs.<hr />- **SSP & Performance**: Server-Side Rendering (SSR) improves load times and SEO but introduces hydration complexities.<hr />- **SPA Characteristics**: Provides smooth, app-like navigation but with large initial JavaScript bundles leading to longer loading times.<hr />- **Hydration Issue**: Complete page hydration increases Time to Interactive (TTI) unnecessarily, leading to "hydration waste".<hr />- **Partial Hydration Concept**: Focus only on hydrating interactive components to optimize JavaScript delivery and improve load times.<hr />- **Implementation**: Some frameworks like Astro and Marko support partial hydration. React requires complex setup for similar benefits.<hr />- **Use Cases**: Choose MPA for static sites or low-interactivity applications; opt for SPA with SSR for highly interactive platforms.<hr />- **Framework Recommendations**: Explore Astro for partial hydration; traditional React can still create MPAs with SSR.

194.title: An Introduction to Atomic CSS
194.description: This article provides an overview of Atomic CSS, including its definition, variations, purposes, and how it compares to other CSS approaches.
194.spr_content: - **Atomic CSS**: CSS architecture using small, single-purpose classes named for visual function; also known as Functional CSS or CSS utilities.<hr />- **Examples of Atomic CSS**: Tailwind CSS, Windi CSS, Tachyons, Bootstrap, Chakra UI.<hr />  <hr />### Variations<hr />- **Static**: Defined like normal CSS with unit-based systems for spacing, color, typography. Advantages include ease of use and clarity.<hr />- **Programmatic**: Uses build tools to auto-generate styles based on HTML; optimizes stylesheets, allowing spontaneous and flexible design.<hr /><hr />### Purposes<hr />- **Simplicity**: Immutable classes, clear naming, and unambiguous utility use prevent unintended consequences.<hr />- **Consistency**: Unit-based styling ensures scalable design; promotes collaboration between designers and developers.<hr />  <hr />### Comparison with Inline Styles<hr />- Atomic CSS is distinct from inline styles; it allows for better reusability without tedious manual replacements.<hr />- **Reusability**: Components can easily integrate styles, simplifying design updates using libraries like React.<hr />- **Abstraction**: Enables centralized style changes, enhancing maintainability.<hr />- **Tooling**: Supports tooling like Sass and PostCSS, enhancing productivity over inline styles.<hr />  <hr />### Advantages of Atomic CSS<hr />- **Brevity**: Terse syntax reduces typing and maintains clarity (e.g., `mt-0` vs `margin-top: 0`).<hr />- **Specificity**: Lower specificity than inline styles increases versatility.<hr />- **Possibilities**: Supports features inline styles don’t, like media queries and animations.<hr />  <hr />### Coexistence<hr />- Atomic CSS is not an all-or-nothing solution; it can complement other styling approaches when appropriate, especially for complex components.<hr /><hr />### References<hr />- Articles discussing Atomic CSS and its implications within modern web development.

195.title: Webassembly
195.description: WebAssembly (abbreviated *Wasm*) was launched in 2017 as a low-level assembly-like language with a compact binary format, so it’s fast to load, execute, and run with near-native performance.
195.spr_content: - WebAssembly (Wasm): initiated in 2017; assembly-like language; compact binary format.  <hr />- Designed for rapid loading and execution; near-native performance.  <hr />- Portable target for high-level languages: C, C++, Rust; compiled, not written directly.  <hr />- JavaScript: interpreted; dynamic variable types; type monitoring required during execution.  <hr />- WebAssembly: pre-compiled; variable types known ahead; streamlined browser processing into machine code.  <hr />- High-Level Goals:  <hr />  - Speed: near-native execution speed across platforms.  <hr />  - Readability: human-readable text format for easier debugging.  <hr />  - Security: operates in a sandboxed environment; adheres to same-origin policy.  <hr />  - Compatibility: integrates well with web technologies; backward compatibility maintained.  <hr />- Use Cases:  <hr />  - Image/video editing, peer-to-peer apps (games, collaborative tools).  <hr />  - Music apps, live video enhancement, VR/AR (low latency).  <hr />  - Scientific visualization/simulation, developer tools (editors, debuggers).  <hr />  - Enterprise application clients (databases).  <hr />- References: MDN WebAssembly, official Wasm site, "WebAssembly in Action," XenonStack guide.

196.title: Parse, don't validate in TypeScript
196.description: The "parse, don't validate" approach is about processing incoming data and failing in a controlled manner if parsing fails.
196.spr_content: - **"Parse, don't validate":** Focuses on processing data efficiently and failing fast if parsing encounters issues.<hr />- **Secure data handling:** Ensures all incoming data is dealt with at system edges.<hr />- **Immediate parsing:** Avoids deep code integration, allowing for quicker failure detection.<hr />- **Explicit data handling:** Requires that each incoming data point is explicitly processed.<hr />- **Type safety:** Reduces risk of harmful data in applications and storage by ensuring types align with schema.<hr />- **Parsing vs. validation:** Parsing inherently incorporates validation but emphasizes structure and type adherence.<hr />  <hr />### Parsing Essentials<hr />- **Definition:** Analyzing strings/symbols within formal grammar rules.<hr />- **Key Concepts:** <hr />  - **Schema & Type:** Unified representation of data structure and constraints.<hr />  - **Analysis Process:** Code adjusts incoming data to fit schema.<hr /><hr />### TypeScript Examples<hr />1. **Basic Schema Creation:**<hr />   ```ts<hr />   let schema = yup.object().shape({<hr />     name: yup.string().required(),<hr />     age: yup.number().required().positive().integer(),<hr />     email: yup.string().email(),<hr />   });<hr />   ```<hr />   <hr />2. **Data Validation:**<hr />   - Incoming data remains `any`, posing a risk without type alignment.<hr />  <hr />3. **Type Casting Limitations:**<hr />   - Manual synchronization between schema and types increases overhead and risk of mismatch.<hr /><hr />4. **Custom Parsing Function:**<hr />   - Constructs assertions to verify type correctness:<hr />   ```ts<hr />   const parseToUserType = (x: any): UserType | Error => {<hr />     if (!isString(name)) return new Error('invalid name');<hr />     if (!isPositiveInteger(age)) return new Error('invalid age');<hr />     return { age, name, email, website };<hr />   };<hr />   ```<hr /><hr />### Business Logic Enhancements<hr />- Improved clarity and predictability by transforming any incoming data into a defined `UserType`.<hr />- Minimized risk through type checks confined to parsing logic.<hr />- Enhanced type safety and driven by TypeScript's compiler support.<hr /><hr />### References<hr />- For additional reading, consult articles on parsing strategies and type handling in TypeScript.

197.file_path: playground/Frontend/Build polymorphic React components with Typescript.md
197.title: Build polymorphic React components with Typescript
197.description: This article provides a step-by-step guide on how to build polymorphic React components with Typescript, covering the necessary concepts and techniques to create flexible and reusable components.
197.spr_content:
- **Objective**: Create a polymorphic `Text` component in React using TypeScript.
- **Basic Structure**:
- Props include `children`, optional `size`, `color`, `className`.
- Renders as a `

` by default using `React.ElementType`.

- **Semantic HTML Enhancement**:
- Introduce `as` prop for rendering different HTML tags (e.g., `

`, `

`).

- **Type Safety**:
- Use `React.ElementType` to restrict `as` prop to valid HTML elements.
- Improve typing to involve `React.ComponentPropsWithoutRef` for additional properties specific to the tag.
- **Handling Default Types**:
- Set default type for `C` in generics to `'p'` for fallback.
- **Omitting Internal Props**:
- Use `Omit, keyof Props>` to exclude properties that belong to intrinsic HTML elements, which allows custom props like `color` and `size`.
- **Reusable Solution**:
- Abstract `as` prop into its own type, `AsProp`.
- Create `PolymorphicComponentProps` type to manage props generically.
- **Ref Forwarding**:
- Utilize `React.forwardRef` for components to pass refs correctly.
- Define a new helper type `PolymorphicRef` for managing ref types in polymorphic components.
- **Final Implementation**:
- The final structure includes `Text` and `Button` components, both supporting polymorphism and ref forwarding with strict TypeScript checks.
- **Example Usage**:
- `Heading`
- `Username`
- ``
- ``
- **Key Takeaway**: Achieved a strongly typed, reusable, and polymorphic component structure in React with TypeScript, ensuring robust type safety and flexibility.

198.title: HSL Color
198.description: HSL is the answer to resolving all of the painful points of Hexadecimal color codes.
198.spr_content: - Frontend engineers use Hexadecimal color codes for color representation.<hr />- Hex codes have limitations: hard to write, adjust, and remember.<hr />- HSL (Hue, Saturation, Lightness) addresses these issues.<hr />- HSL is derived from the RGB color wheel.<hr />- **Hue**: 0° to 360°; red at 0°/360°, green at 120°, blue at 240°; wraps around modulus 360.<hr />- **Saturation**: 0% = grayscale, 100% = full color.<hr />- **Lightness**: 0% = black, 100% = white, 50% = midpoint lightness.<hr />- HSL enables intuitive color manipulation, such as creating darker/lighter button states.<hr />- Example of CSS usage: utilizing HSL for dynamic color changes on hover.<hr />- By adjusting lightness, a range of color shades can be generated for UI consistency.<hr />- HSL supports transparency (HSLa) with an alpha channel (0 to 1).<hr />- HSL offers programmatic control of color in CSS, enhancing accessibility for designers.

199.title: Why Virtual DOM is fast?
199.description: React and Vue, two popular front-end frameworks, both use Virtual DOM to improve page rendering efficiency. Understanding the concept of Virtual DOM sheds light on an important aspect of performance optimization on the client side.
199.spr_content: - React and Vue utilize Virtual DOM for rendering efficiency.<hr />- Virtual DOM is a mapping of JavaScript objects to the actual DOM.<hr />- Example of Virtual DOM structure provided in React context.<hr />- Virtual DOM translates to HTML through a specific hierarchy.<hr />- One-to-one mapping between Virtual DOM and browser DOM enhances rendering.<hr />- Performance optimization hinges on state change management in React.<hr />  <hr />Steps during state change:<hr />- Generate new Virtual DOM.<hr />- Compare new and previous Virtual DOMs.<hr />- Create a diff object for changes.<hr />- Update actual DOM based on the diff object.<hr />  <hr />Changes from an initial to a new Virtual DOM illustrate:<hr />- Unchanged elements remain untouched.<hr />- New props are registered in the diff object.<hr />- Empty children arrays note deletions.<hr />  <hr />Batch updates to the actual DOM minimize method calls and update frequencies.<hr />  <hr />Key benefits identified:<hr />- Grouping updates reduces render time.<hr />- Identifying unnecessary changes prevents redundant updates.<hr />  <hr />Fewer DOM updates enhance performance by decreasing computation needs.<hr />- "Diffing" is cheaper than direct DOM manipulation.<hr />  <hr />Conclusion: Virtual DOM is slower than expected but more efficient than direct DOM updates.

200.title: Render optimization in data-fetching libraries
200.description: Data-fetching libraries are software tools or frameworks that can help improve the performance and scalability of your application by handling network requests and data processing more efficiently.
200.spr_content: - Data-fetching libraries enhance application performance and scalability.<hr />- They efficiently manage network requests and data processing.<hr />- In React, they optimize rendering to prevent unnecessary component re-renders.<hr />- Unchanged data should not trigger multiple renders, improving efficiency.<hr />  <hr />**Deduplication:**<hr />- Caching strategies minimize network requests.<hr />- Utilizes unique keys for identification; employs stale-while-revalidate for validation.<hr />- Caching returns data from local storage or triggers a network request.<hr /><hr />**Data Selection:**<hr />- Requests update components with three stateful values: data, error, fetching.<hr />- `fetching` can lead to unnecessary renders if not managed properly.<hr />- Recommended to destructure state when using hooks to limit re-renders.<hr /><hr />**Structural Sharing:**<hr />- Advanced technique that optimizes rendering by preserving data structure identity.<hr />- Compares previous and new states to retain unchanged elements.<hr />- Essential for efficient partial subscriptions in large datasets.<hr />- Structural sharing can be a bottleneck; use cautiously.<hr /><hr />**References:**<hr />- React Query documentation for render optimizations.<hr />- Next.js data-fetching guides.<hr />- SWR performance documentation.<hr />- TanStack Query documentation on caching.

201.title: Window and iframe communication
201.description: When working with web development, communicating between a main window and an embedded iframe is often necessary for various tasks, such as content creation or widget implementation. This communication can occur between windows and iframes with the same origin or across different origins.
201.spr_content: - Web development often requires communication between main window and embedded iframe for tasks like content creation and widget implementation.<hr />- "Same origin" means URLs share protocol, domain, and port; example: `http://example.com`.<hr />- Same origin communication allows full access to iframe content.<hr />- Different origins restrict access for security reasons (e.g., different domain, subdomain, protocol, or port).<hr />- Same origin example: manipulate iframe content via `contentWindow` or `contentDocument`.<hr />- Use cases include content builders needing isolated CSS and responsive displays.<hr />- Cross origin communication occurs with different origins, facilitated by `postMessage` interface.<hr />- The `postMessage` method enables information exchange between origins under user-agreed conditions.<hr />- Communication process: <hr />  - Parent uses `iframe.contentWindow.postMessage` to send messages.<hr />  - Iframe uses `window.parent.postMessage` to send messages back.<hr />  - Both parties handle messages with `window.addEventListener('message')`.<hr />- Cross origin example: iframe and parent exchange messages using `postMessage`.<hr />- Use cases include embedded widgets like chatboxes.<hr />- Summary: Use `postMessage` for cross origin and `contentWindow` for same origin to enhance web application integration and functionality.

202.title: Why Micro Frontend
202.description: As web applications become more complex and feature-rich, traditional frontend architectures such as monolithic will become harder to maintain, scale, and evolve. Micro-frontend is an emerging front-end architecture that aims to address these challenges by breaking down the front-end into small, independent and reusable modules.
202.spr_content: - **Micro-Frontend Definition**: Architectural pattern for frontend development; breaks frontend into small, independent, self-contained modules.<hr />  <hr />- **Comparison to Monolithic Architecture**: Monolithic systems have a single repository, complicating updates and scaling; micro-frontend mitigates these issues through modularization.<hr /><hr />- **Design Principles**:<hr />  - **Single Responsibility**: Each module handles a specific feature.<hr />  - **Loose Coupling**: Minimize interdependencies; modules operate independently.<hr />  - **Composability**: Modules are easily combined into a full application.<hr />  - **Isolation**: Modules operate in their own dedicated context, preventing interference.<hr />  - **Standardization**: Adhere to consistent design patterns and coding practices.<hr />  - **Testing**: Incorporate automated tests for reliability and stability.<hr /><hr />- **Advantages**:<hr />  - **Scalability**: Features can scale independently.<hr />  - **Flexibility**: Use diverse frameworks and technologies.<hr />  - **Faster Development & Deployment**: Teams work independently, reducing coordination overhead.<hr />  - **Maintainability**: Easier to manage, rebuild, and fix individual components.<hr /><hr />- **Challenges**:<hr />  - **Increased Complexity**: Managing interactions and dependencies can complicate architecture.<hr />  - **Performance Overhead**: Adds network requests and resources that can affect load times.<hr />  - **Browser Compatibility**: Variability in dependencies complicates cross-browser functionality.<hr />  - **Security Concerns**: Each module is a potential attack vector; requires careful isolation.<hr />  - **Communication Complexity**: Coordination between modules for complex workflows needs meticulous design.<hr />  - **Tooling and Infrastructure Needs**: Requires new tools and expertise for effective deployment.<hr /><hr />- **Real-World Adoption**: Companies like AWS, IKEA, and DAZN use micro-frontend architecture, highlighting its industry relevance.<hr /><hr />- **Conclusion**: Micro-frontend enhances scalability and maintainability but is not universally suitable; careful evaluation against traditional architectures is essential for effective implementation.

203.file_path: playground/Frontend/URL formats for sharing via social networks.md
203.title: URL formats for sharing via social networks
203.description: Each social network has its own unique way of handling URLs, and understanding the correct formatting can make a significant difference in the visibility and engagement of your shared content.
203.spr_content: - **Context:** Rise of social platforms (Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn) enables quick URL sharing.<hr />- **Impact:** Correct URL formatting enhances visibility and engagement.<hr />  <hr />- **Facebook Sharing Format:**<hr />  - URL structure: `https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=${url}`<hr />  - Interaction: Shares dialog with specified content.<hr /><hr />- **Messenger Sharing Format:**<hr />  - URL Structure: `https://www.facebook.com/dialog/send?app_id=${appId}&display=popup&link=${url}&redirect_uri=${url}`<hr />  - Requires: Facebook App ID and target URL.<hr /><hr />- **Zalo Sharing Format:**<hr />  - Method: Create JSON object with `"url"` key, base64 encode.<hr />  - Example Code: <hr />    ```javascript<hr />    function encodeB64(str: string) { return window.btoa(str); }<hr />    const sharingUrl = `https://button-share.zalo.me/share_external?d=${encodeB64(JSON.stringify({ url }))}`;<hr />    ```<hr /><hr />- **Other Platforms Formats:**<hr />  - LinkedIn: `https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=${url}`<hr />  - Twitter: `http://twitter.com/share?url=${url}`<hr />  - Telegram: `https://telegram.me/share/?url=${url}`<hr />  - Reddit: `https://www.reddit.com/submit?url=${url}&title=${title}`

204.title: WAI-ARIA
204.description: WAI-ARIA is a technology that can help with the problems of modern websites and applications containing huge amounts of dynamic content and complex components with no semantics to describe what they mean.
204.spr_content: - Web accessibility challenges: Dynamic content, complex components, lack of semantics hinder user interaction.<hr />- Users with disabilities rely on assistive technologies (e.g., Screen Readers, text-to-speech, screen magnification).<hr />- WAI-ARIA (Web Accessibility Initiative - Accessible Rich Internet Applications) aids in web accessibility.<hr />- WAI-ARIA features: Roles, States, Properties enhance semantics and accessibility.<hr />  <hr />  **Roles**:<hr />  - Define what HTML components are or do.<hr />  - Example: `<a role="button">` recognized as a button by screen readers.<hr />  - Can describe webpage sections: `navigation`, `main`, `banner`.<hr /><hr />  **Properties**:<hr />  - Represent associated data values, less subject to change.<hr />  - Examples: `aria-label`, `aria-required`, `aria-describedby`.<hr /><hr />  **States**:<hr />  - Similar to properties but frequently change during a component's lifecycle.<hr />  - Examples: `aria-pressed`, `aria-expanded`, `aria-selected`.<hr /><hr />- WAI-ARIA attributes do not alter component behavior, but enhance information for assistive technologies.<hr />- Uses of WAI-ARIA:<hr />  - Define webpage regions with roles (e.g., banner, navigation).<hr />  - Inform users of dynamic updates (via `aria-live`).<hr />  - Support keyboard navigation with `tabindex`.<hr />  - Improve accessibility of non-semantic components through roles and properties.<hr />  <hr />- WAI-ARIA helps create an inclusive online experience by enhancing usability for users with disabilities.

205.title: Variable Fonts
205.description: Variable fonts are a font format that allows for a single font file to contain multiple variations of a typeface.
205.spr_content: - **Variable Font**: Also known as OpenType Font Variations; a single file contains multiple typeface variations.<hr />- **Axes of Variations**: Characteristics or parameters of a font, such as weight, width, and style, that define its variations.<hr />- **Weight Axis Example**: Ranges from "Thin" to "Bold"; any value within creates unique styles.<hr />- **Customization**: Designers can create specific font styles by manipulating axes.<hr />- **Benefits**: <hr />  - **Size Efficiency**: Combines various styles in one file, reducing size and load time.<hr />  - **Flexibility**: Allows precise adjustments to meet design needs.<hr />  - **Creativity**: Encourages experimentation and distinct typography.<hr />- **Usage**: <hr />  - Load fonts using `@font-face` with formats for compatibility.<hr />  - Apply variations via `font-variation-settings`, using pairs of axis tags and values.<hr />- **Registered Axes**: Include weight (`wght`), width (`wdth`), optical size (`opsz`), slant (`slnt`), or italics (`ital`).<hr />- **Resources**: Explore variable fonts through interactive sites and examples to understand their functionality.<hr />- **Development Tip**: Customize axes according to specific design capabilities of the font.

206.title: ViteJS native modules
206.description: ViteJS takes full advantage of the availability of native ES modules in the browser and the rise of JavaScript tools written in compile-to-native languages by introducing pre-bundles dependancies using esbuild.
206.spr_content: - Lack of native JavaScript module support led to bundling tools like Webpack, Rollup, and Parcel.<hr />- Increasing module counts in projects result in performance bottlenecks for JavaScript-based tools.<hr />- Vite leverages native ES modules, enhancing performance and developer experience.<hr />- Vite introduces pre-bundled dependencies via `esbuild`, a Go-based tool, significantly faster than JavaScript-based alternatives.<hr />- Traditional bundle-based development servers (like Webpack) rebuild the entire application upon changes, leading to inefficiency.<hr />- Vite utilizes a native ESM-based dev server, bundling only on-demand via HTTP requests, improving speed and efficiency.<hr />- HMR (Hot Module Replacement) in Vite enables quick updates by invalidating only the relevant chain upon file changes, maintaining performance regardless of app size.<hr />- Although native ESM is supported, production deployment without bundling is inefficient due to increased network round trips from nested imports.<hr />- Bundling is still preferred for production for benefits like tree-shaking, lazy-loading, and chunk splitting for better performance and caching.<hr />- While `esbuild` is fast, it lacks key features for application bundling, such as code-splitting and CSS handling; `Rollup` remains more versatile for production needs.

207.title: From Markup to Pixels - A look inside the DOM, CSSOM, and Render Tree
207.description: A deep dive into the rendering process of a web page, exploring the Document Object Model (DOM), CSS Object Model (CSSOM), and the Render Tree.
207.spr_content: - The browser engine determines web content display based on data input.<hr />- Major browsers use distinct engine names: Firefox (Gecko), Chrome (Blink, a WebKit derivative).<hr />- The process from HTML bytes to the DOM involves several steps.<hr />  - Bytes of HTML are read and converted to characters.<hr />  - Characters are parsed into tokens (e.g., HTML tags).<hr />  - Tokens are organized into nodes to form the hierarchical DOM structure.<hr />- CSS parsing begins on encountering a `link` tag, producing the CSS Object Model (CSSOM).<hr />- Specificity in CSS determines which styles are applied to nodes when multiple CSS files are present.<hr />- The Render Tree combines the DOM and CSSOM, detailing node visibility and respective styles.<hr />- Layout/Reflow calculates the geometry of elements, storing x, y coordinates, and dimensions through a layout tree.<hr />- Changes to the DOM or viewport trigger the Layout/Reflow process.<hr />- Painting renders the visual aspects of the page.<hr />  - Painting is repetitive, occurring with any visual element changes.<hr />  - The browser organizes painting into layers for efficiency.<hr />- Compositing involves managing layers independently to optimize rendering, crucial for smooth animations and scrolling.<hr />- The compositor thread handles layer rendering, breaking large layers into tiles for raster threads to process.<hr />- Efficient rendering relies on a structured Layer tree and tile management for GPU memory.

208.title: Parallelism in JavaScript
208.description: Parallelism in JavaScript is a technique to improve the performance of web applications by executing multiple tasks simultaneously.
208.spr_content: - Web applications dominate modern software development.<hr />- JavaScript as a mainstream, single-threaded language faces performance limits.<hr />- Heavyweight applications (image processing, online games, data mining) necessitate parallelism.<hr />  <hr />- **Web Worker**: Initial parallelism model for web browsers.<hr />  - Executes JavaScript in a separate thread.<hr />  - Does not disrupt user interface.<hr />  - Runs in a distinct context; no access to `document` or `window`.<hr />  - XMLHttpRequest, WebSocket, data storage are accessible.<hr />  <hr />- Types of workers:<hr />  - **Dedicated Worker**: Accessible only from the initiating script.<hr />  - **Shared Worker**: Multiple scripts can access state.<hr />  <hr />- Communication:<hr />  - Utilizes `postMessage()` for sending data.<hr />  - Responses via `onmessage` event handler.<hr />  - Data is serializable (copied), causing performance bottlenecks for large data transfers.<hr /><hr />- Example code illustrates worker creation and message handling.<hr /><hr />- **WebCL**: JavaScript binding for OpenCL.<hr />  - Aims to utilize GPU and multi-core CPU parallel processing in browsers.<hr />  - Currently lacks native browser support; requires non-native add-ons.<hr /><hr />- **RiverTrail**: OpenCL-based framework for data parallel programming in JavaScript.<hr />  - Extends JavaScript with data-parallel constructs.<hr />  - Translated to low-level hardware abstract layer at runtime.<hr /><hr />- Most OpenCL frameworks are inactive due to lack of browser support.<hr />- Shift in focus to technologies like **WebAssembly** and **WebGPU** for performance improvement.<hr /><hr />- **Conclusion**: Web Worker remains the primary method for achieving parallelism in production web applications.

209.title: Atomic Design Pattern
209.description: Atomic design is a methodology for crafting design systems with five key fundamental building blocks, which, when combined, promote consistency, modularity, and scalability.
209.spr_content: - Atomic Design: Methodology for design systems with five building blocks.<hr />- Promotes consistency, modularity, scalability.<hr />- Flexible designs for frontend engineers from inception.<hr />- Transitions from abstract concepts to concrete implementations.<hr />- Aligns well with component-based architectures (React, Vue).<hr /><hr />### Five Levels of Atomic Design:<hr />1. **Atoms**: Basic building blocks (e.g., HTML tags like inputs, buttons).<hr />   - Abstract elements, minimally functional alone.<hr />   <hr />2. **Molecules**: Combined atoms (e.g., form input with labels).<hr />   - Simple functional units adding context to atoms.<hr />   <hr />3. **Organisms**: Groups of molecules forming complex interface sections.<hr />   - Distinct, functional components of a web interface.<hr />   <hr />4. **Templates**: Collections of organisms for page layouts.<hr />   - Wireframes that evolve into layouts without real data.<hr />   <hr />5. **Pages**: Specific instances of templates with real content.<hr />   - Represents what users will ultimately experience.<hr /><hr />### Atomic Design Folder Structure:<hr />- Organizes components in five distinct layers, customizable by preferences. <hr />- Supports coherent application architecture.<hr /><hr />### References:<hr />- Brad Frost’s insights on atomic web design.<hr />- Practical applications in structuring React applications.<hr />- Related techniques and principles in atomic design.

210.title: Singleton Design Pattern in Javascript
210.description: The Singleton design pattern is a design pattern that restricts the instantiation of a class to one object.
210.spr_content: - **Global State Management**: Alternatives available in frameworks like ReactJs: Redux, React Context, Recoil, MobX.<hr />- **Vanilla JavaScript**: Use design patterns for specific state management to minimize bundle size and avoid excessive instances.<hr />- **Singleton Design Pattern**: Ensures a class has only one static instance accessible throughout the application.<hr />- **Implementation**: <hr />  - Class (`MyNameClass`) holds a property (`_name`).<hr />  - Singleton function returns an instance only if it doesn’t already exist.<hr />  - `getInstance` method creates the instance if necessary, otherwise returns the existing one.<hr />- **Example Usage**: <hr />  - Instances (`instanceOne`, `instanceTwo`) show shared state as both reference the same object.<hr />  - Changing `name` in one instance reflects in the other, confirming they are identical.<hr />- **Pros**: <hr />  - Guarantees single instance of a class.<hr />  - Provides global access point.<hr />  - Instance initialized only once.<hr />- **Cons**: <hr />  - Violates Single Responsibility Principle (SRP); a class may assume multiple responsibilities.<hr />  - Complicates unit testing.<hr />- **Conclusion**: Useful for globally accessed, infrequently changed data, such as database connections or user configurations.

211.title: What is PNPM Compare To NPM/Yarn
211.description: PNPM is a package manager for Node.js which stands for “Performant NPM”. It was introduced in 2016, the same year Yarn was released. PNPM is a fast, disk space efficient package manager that supports monorepos. It creates a non-flat `node_modules` by default, so code has no access to arbitrary packages.
211.spr_content: - PNPM is a package manager for Node.js, meaning "Performant NPM."<hr />- Introduced in 2016, alongside Yarn.<hr />- Focused on speed and disk space efficiency.<hr />- Supports monorepos and non-flat `node_modules` directory structure.<hr />- Installation process consists of three stages:<hr />  1. Dependency resolution.<hr />  2. Directory structure calculation.<hr />  3. Linking dependencies.<hr />- Advantages include:<hr />  - Reduced disk space usage through content-addressable store.<hr />  - Faster installations compared to NPM/Yarn.<hr />  - Non-flat directory avoids access to arbitrary packages.<hr />- Content-addressable store links packages globally, preventing duplication.<hr />- Non-flat structure maintains a clearer, organized dependency tree.<hr />- Initial installation may be slower than Yarn or NPM.<hr />- Compatibility issues possible with older packages and certain build tools.<hr />- Symbolic links can create access problems on some systems (e.g., Windows, permissioned Linux).<hr />- Well-regarded, used by many large companies.<hr />- Overall, PNPM presents unique advantages worth exploring for users’ projects.

212.title: Intro to IndexedDB
212.description: IndexedDB is a low-level API for client-side storage like localStorage and cookies. But this built-in non-relational database is much more powerful than those 2 counterparts.
212.spr_content: - **IndexedDB**: Low-level API for client-side storage; more powerful than localStorage and cookies.<hr />- **Key Use Case**: Ideal for offline applications (e.g., to-do lists, saved games) requiring persistent local data storage.<hr />- **Characteristics**:<hr />  - Stores key-value pairs, including complex objects.<hr />  - Operates asynchronously.<hr />  - Handles significant volumes of structured data.<hr />  - Supports transactions for reliability.<hr />  - Does not utilize SQL.<hr />- **Same-Origin Policy**: Access restrictions based on domain; data is not sharable across different domains.<hr /><hr />### Terminologies<hr />- **Database**: Contains object stores; identified by a constant name and version.<hr />  - Example: Opening a database involves specifying its name and version.<hr />- **Object Store**: Core component; akin to tables in relational databases; each store must have a unique name within its database.<hr />  - Example: Creating an object store involves defining the name and key path.<hr />- **Transaction**: Atomic data-access and modification operations; all operations must either succeed or fail.<hr />  - Multiple active transactions allowed, provided they do not overlap.<hr />- **Index**: Specialized store for looking up records; key-value storage related to another object store.<hr />  - Indices automatically update with insertions, updates, or deletions in referenced objects.<hr />- **Cursor**: Traverses object store; retrieves records one at a time, conserving memory.<hr />  - Essential for handling extensive data sets.<hr /><hr />### Limitations<hr />- Not designed for:<hr />  - Internationalized string sorting.<hr />  - Server-side database synchronization.<hr />  - Full text searching (no equivalent to SQL's `LIKE`).<hr />- Potential errors unrelated to developer control, e.g.:<hr />  - Browser restrictions in private mode (e.g. Firefox, Edge).<hr />  - Device storage limitations.<hr />- **Complex Coding**: More intricate compared to localStorage or cookies; worth it for complex object storage or transactional requirements. <hr /><hr />### References<hr />- Additional resources for implementing and understanding IndexedDB.

213.title: Why We Chose Our Tech Stack Accelerating Development With A Robust Frontend Solution
213.description: At Dwarves Foundation, we pride ourselves on being a team of seasoned technology experts, passionate about crafting innovative solutions for our clients. With years of experience in the technology industry, we understand the importance of selecting the right tools and technologies to deliver exceptional results. In today's fast-paced world, staying ahead of the competition requires building and deploying features quickly without sacrificing quality or stability.
213.spr_content: - Dwarves Foundation: Expert technology team, innovative solutions, client-focused.<hr />- Emphasis on tool selection for exceptional outcomes, stressing stability and maturity.<hr />- Fast-paced competitive landscape demands quick feature deployment without quality loss.<hr />- Tech stack components enable rapid, scalable application development.<hr />  <hr />**Key Technologies:**<hr />- **React:** Stable, high-performance framework; strong community support; steeper learning curve but invaluable for long-term projects.<hr />- **Next.js:** Ideal for scaling React applications; features hybrid rendering, TypeScript support, and intelligent bundling; adds complexity, but benefits outweigh drawbacks.<hr />- **React Context API:** Simplifies local state management, avoids complex libraries when not necessary; encourages efficiency and maintainability.<hr />- **TypeScript:** Enhances robustness; compile-time error detection; aids collaboration and code quality; gradual migration from JavaScript is feasible.<hr />- **SWR:** Caches backend data for dynamic UIs; optimizes data retrieval but needs careful configuration to avoid performance issues.<hr />- **React Hook Forms:** Balances performance with simplicity for form management; can be extended as needed.<hr />- **TailwindCSS:** Utility-first CSS framework; promotes consistency, mobile-first design, and customization; removes unused CSS in production.<hr /><hr />**Architecture Layers:**<hr />- **Service Connector:** Uses Fetch API for efficient communication between frontend and backend; integrates well with SWR for caching and error handling.<hr />- **State Management:** React Context for local and SWR for global state; facilitates component data access seamlessly.<hr />- **Logic:** React Hooks encapsulate business logic for maintainability and reusability; clear separation of concerns.<hr />- **UI Layer:** Combines TailwindCSS with HeadlessUI for accessible, customizable components; trade-off of initial development time for ongoing flexibility.<hr /><hr />**Testing Strategy:**<hr />- **Jest:** Main framework for JavaScript tests; optimized with parallel testing capabilities.<hr />- **React Testing Library:** Focuses on user-centric component testing to reduce maintenance burden.<hr />- **Cypress:** Powerful for end-to-end testing; simulates user interactions effectively despite browser support limitations.<hr /><hr />**Conclusion:**<hr />- Dwarves Foundation’s tech stack and architecture ensure competitive advantage through quality, speed, and adaptability.<hr />- Commitment to testing practices elevates user experience and application reliability.<hr />- Invitation for partnerships with potential clients seeking scalable frontend solutions.

214.file_path: playground/Frontend/Tackling Server State complexity in Frontend Development.md
214.title: Tackling Server State complexity in Frontend Development
214.description: Frontend development has become increasingly complex over the years, and with it, the need for efficient state management.
214.spr_content: - Frontend complexity necessitates efficient state management.<hr />- Global State mitigates prop drilling by sharing state across components.<hr />- Cleaner, maintainable code through reduced data passing.<hr />- Global State has limitations, particularly with server-state data.<hr />- Applications handle Client State (client-controlled) vs. Server State (remotely persisted).<hr />- Historical conflation of Client and Server State as Global State.<hr />- Global State synchronization entails caching, memory management, and background updates.<hr />- Redux users face challenges storing API responses, requiring boilerplate for loading and error handling.<hr />- Libraries like SWR and React-Query address server-state management effectively.<hr />- Comparison: Redux requires extensive boilerplate; React-Query offers concise code.<hr />- Global State management useful but consider limitations with Server State.<hr />- Assess the need for Global State when dealing with server-state data.<hr />- Use libraries like SWR and React-Query for simplifying server-state complexities.

215.title: Remix Versus Nextjs
215.description: A brief comparison between Remix and Next.js frameworks
215.spr_content: - **Remix Overview**: Edge native, full-stack JavaScript framework; focuses on user experience, unifying client and server; encourages product-centric thinking.<hr />- **Next.js Overview**: Popular React framework for server-side rendering; established presence and community.<hr />- **Rendering Strategies**: <hr />  - Remix: No Static Site Generation (SSG); uses HTTP stale-while-revalidate caching for dynamic content.<hr />  - Next.js: Supports SSG and various pre-rendering methods.<hr />- **Routing**: <hr />  - Both use file-based systems.<hr />  - Remix: Routes in `/app/routes` directory; robust nested routing via React Router, requires Outlet for rendering.<hr />  - Next.js: Routes in `/pages` directory; simpler, less flexible nested routing.<hr />- **Data Loading**: <hr />  - Next.js: Multiple methods (e.g., `getServerSideProps`, `getStaticProps`).<hr />  - Remix: Utilizes `loader` functions and `useLoaderData` hook for streamlined data access.<hr />- **Data Mutation**: <hr />  - Next.js: Manual process for forms, state management, and error handling.<hr />  - Remix: Simplifies with `<Form>` component and `action` functions for automatic data updates and UI reflection.<hr />- **Error Handling**: <hr />  - Next.js: Custom error pages for certain statuses, limited data error handling.<hr />  - Remix: Error boundaries per route, allowing localized error catching and hierarchical bubbling.<hr />- **Conclusion**: <hr />  - Next.js remains the go-to for its familiarity and strong community; stable, hard to displace.<hr />  - Remix offers modern features and abstractions, promising improved developer experience and potential growth.

216.title: Shadow DOM
216.description: Shadow DOM is a web standard that allows encapsulation of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript within a specific context.
216.spr_content: - **Concept Overview**: Javis - an AI Chrome extension enhancing web experiences.<hr />- **Challenge**: CSS clash between Javis and webpage distortions.<hr />- **Solution**: Shadow DOM - encapsulates HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.<hr />- **Definition**: Shadow DOM allows hidden trees in standard DOM, initiated by a shadow root.<hr />- **Terminology**:<hr />  - **Shadow Host**: Regular DOM node for attaching Shadow DOM.<hr />  - **Shadow Tree**: DOM tree within the Shadow DOM.<hr />  - **Shadow Boundary**: Transition point from Shadow DOM to regular DOM.<hr />  - **Shadow Root**: Root node of the Shadow Tree.<hr />- **Manipulation**: Nodes in Shadow DOM can be manipulated like regular nodes; encapsulation prevents external impact.<hr />- **Creation**: Use `Element.attachShadow()` with mode options:<hr />  - `open`: Accessible Shadow DOM.<hr />  - `closed`: Inaccessible Shadow DOM (e.g., `<video>` tag).<hr />- **Significance**: Enhances reliability and user experience; prevents CSS and script clashes.<hr />- **Applications**: Ideal for website extensions and interactive components.<hr />- **Resources**: MDN documentation on Shadow DOM.

217.title: Why DOM manipulation is slow?
217.description: Actually, the DOM is not slow. Adding or removing a DOM node is not much more than setting a property on the JS object. However, _layout_ is slow. Imagine adding a DOM node changes the height of the document, it would invoke a bunch of [rendering processes](https://web.dev/rendering-performance/) to redraw the screen. And all the complex algorithms behind the those processes makes any changes in DOM potentially expensive.
217.spr_content: - The Document Object Model (DOM) operations (adding/removing nodes) are efficient, akin to setting properties on JavaScript objects.  <hr />- Layout processes are the performance bottleneck in DOM manipulation.  <hr />- Adding a node can alter document height, triggering extensive rendering processes.  <hr />- Rendering processes involve complex algorithms that incur computational costs.  <hr />- Changes in the DOM can lead to expensive rendering due to the intricate nature of layout calculations.

218.title: Focus trap
218.description: Focus trap is a web technique to improve accessibility by forcing keyboard focus inside a DOM element, to prevent the user navigating outside that element.
218.spr_content: - Focus trap enhances web accessibility by confining keyboard focus within a specific DOM element.<hr />- Commonly used in open modal dialogs to restrict user interaction to the dialog.<hr />- Prevents focus from escaping the modal, reducing user confusion regarding the active element.<hr />- Ensures a clear state of focus, improving usability for keyboard-navigating users.<hr />- Reference material emphasizes CSS methodologies for implementing focus traps in web design.

219.title: HTML inert
219.description: `inert` is a boolean HTML property that makes the browser ignore the user input events for an element, including focus events and events from assistive technologies.
219.spr_content: - `inert`: Boolean HTML property.<hr />- Prevents user input events (e.g. focus, assistive tech).<hr />- Removes element from tab order (interactivity) and accessibility tree (discoverability).<hr />- Prior suppression of discoverability: `aria-hidden="true"`.<hr />- Prior handling of interactivity: `tabindex="-1"` + `aria-hidden`.<hr />- Simplifies management of dialogs, eliminates need for focus traps.<hr />- Focus must still be managed manually: move to dialog, return to triggering element.<hr />- Example: <hr />  - Before: combination of `aria-hidden` and focus trap.<hr />  - After: `inert` applied for streamlined accessibility.<hr />- References: <hr />  - Web.dev article on `inert`.<hr />  - ARIA demo for `inert` usage.<hr />

222.spr_content: - **Frontend Roundup**: Second half of November 2024 featuring tools and insights.<hr />- **React Router v7**: Introduces `framework mode`, server rendering, improved type safety, templates for new projects, and upgrade guides.<hr />- **State Management Anti-Pattern**: Avoid passing `useState` setters; prefer callback functions for better clarity and maintainability.<hr />- **Next Cloudinary**: Simplifies file handling and optimization in Next.js; supports various file sources and advanced image effects.<hr />- **Solito 4.3**: Bridges React Native and Next.js for shared components and navigation, ensuring consistent user experience.<hr />- **JavaScript Symbols**: Detailed exploration of unique keys, behavior control, and practical applications like `Symbol.toPrimitive`.<hr />- **Library Import Guide**: Insights on importing libraries without a build system; highlights challenges in module systems.<hr />- **CSS Feature Support**: Framework for deciding new CSS usage based on browser support, considering fallbacks and audience stats.<hr />- **Performance Metric Development**: Introduction of CrRRUX to normalize Core Web Vitals for comparability in website performance.<hr />- **Tailwind CSS v4 Beta**: Dramatic performance improvements with unified toolchain and new modern features.<hr />- **Vite 6.0**: Major updates, faster builds, experimental Environment API, and improved framework support.<hr />- **Extism**: Framework for building with WebAssembly across platforms with a flexible plug-in system.<hr />- **Innovative Tools**: Tools like SmarkForm, SVG to Font, and jsontr.ee for enhanced development capabilities.<hr />- **Thought Leadership Articles**: Commentary on IDE preferences, technical debt, and cross-ecosystem impressions in development.

223.spr_content: - **React 19 Release**: Major update introduces built-in error handling and optimistic updates via Actions. New hooks (`useOptimistic`, `useActionState`) enhance development efficiency. Improved Suspense feature boosts performance.<hr />  <hr />- **Ref Callbacks**: In React 19, ref callbacks can now return cleanup functions, allowing DOM measurement through ResizeObserver.<hr /><hr />- **View Transition API**: Experimental API enables smooth transitions and animations in user interfaces, enhancing engagement.<hr /><hr />- **Next.js 15.1**: Now officially supports React 19, offering better debugging tools and error handling. Introduces SSR capability on Deno Deploy for scalability.<hr /><hr />- **Next.js Multi Zones**: Facilitates independent deployments within large teams, enabling distinct teams to manage their sections of applications seamlessly.<hr /><hr />- **Transformers.js**: Client-side AI processing in browsers for tasks like sentiment analysis using an accessible pipeline API.<hr /><hr />- **HTML/CSS Innovations**: New attributes and CSS features simplify interactive elements. Enhancements for `<details>` and `<select>` improve styling and usability.<hr /><hr />- **JavaScript Trends 2024**: Features `shadcn/ui` and `HTMX`, focusing on accessibility and dynamic HTML interactions.<hr /><hr />- **Offline-First Apps**: Essential guide for building resilient applications that function during internet outages, emphasizing data synchronization and caching.<hr /><hr />- **Emerging Development Trends**: Highlights AI tools, server-driven UIs, Next.js with React Server Components, and component-driven design systems.<hr /><hr />- **Tailwind CSS v4.0**: Introduces performance features but raises concerns about CSS variable usage and class naming clarity.<hr /><hr />- **Node.js TypeScript Support**: Upcoming native TypeScript support will streamline development, allowing direct execution of TypeScript code.<hr /><hr />- **Million Tool**: Optimizes React applications by identifying slow components and improving performance via real-time insights.<hr /><hr />- **Commentary**: Reflections on transitioning from React to alternatives like Go and HTMX, challenges with dependency management, and advocating for the open social web.

Better tools for managing form submissions.<hr /><hr />- **SSR Performance Insights**:<hr />  - Performance comparison of SSR among React, Vue, Svelte, Solid, and Preact, highlighting Vue's top performance.<hr /><hr />- **Essential Libraries for React 2024**:<hr />  - Focus on state management (Zustand), UI (Tailwind CSS), data fetching (TanStack Query) for streamlined development.<hr /><hr />- **Next.js 15 Features**:<hr />  - Supports React 19 RC with improved hydration error handling and caching.<hr />  - Introduces experimental features like Partial Prerendering and the React Compiler.<hr /><hr />- **CSS Innovations**:<hr />  - State of CSS 2024 survey opens up new possibilities for advanced CSS functionalities, including animations and scoping effects.<hr /><hr />- **Temporal Proposal**:<hr />  - Aims to improve JS date handling with enhanced features for daylight saving and comparisons.<hr /><hr />- **MUI v6 Release**:<hr />  - Offers CSS theme variables, container queries, and performance enhancements aligned with React 19.<hr /><hr />- **Emerging Technologies**:<hr />  - **InformAI**: Exposes UI data to LLMs for enhanced AI responses.<hr />  - **Rspack 1.0**: High-performance bundler that significantly outperforms webpack, supporting modern JavaScript features.<hr /><hr />- **Developer Tools**:<hr />  - **Waku**: Lightweight platform for enjoyable React development.<hr />  - **Formity**: Simplifies complex form building using JSON.<hr /><hr />- **Trending Languages**:<hr />  - TypeScript and Rust gaining traction, emphasizing reliability and memory safety.<hr /><hr />- **Community Projects**:<hr />  - **e18e**: Focuses on improving JS performance by cleaning up dependencies.<hr /><hr />- **Insights and Commentary**:<hr />  - Discussions on trends in CSS, design practices, and the viability of microfrontends and micro-libraries.<hr />  <hr />- **Quick Links**: Access to tutorials and articles for deeper exploration of topics.

226.spr_content: - **Frontend Development Update**: November 2024 highlights, including React 19, XState, Shopify’s React Native use, Next.js 15, and container queries.  <hr />- **React**: TanStack Start competes with Next.js; focuses on client-first, server-side capabilities. XState simplifies state management, enhancing reliability in React. Shopify migrates mobile app to React Native, reducing code base significantly, improving speed and ratings.  <hr />- **Next.js**: Version 15 improves build speed, Dev experience, React Server Components support, and image optimization. Introduces advanced search param filtering techniques.  <hr />- **Frameworks vs Web Components**: Modern frameworks outperform Web Components in integration and state management.  <hr />- **Container Queries**: Responsive design enhancement by adjusting elements based on parent size; anticipated widespread adoption.  <hr />- **TanStack Start Overview**: Full-stack React framework with type-safe APIs and comprehensive SSR capabilities.  <hr />- **Cost Optimization**: Recall.ai saves $1M annually using Shared Memory optimization.  <hr />- **New Tools**: HTML to React Chrome extension for easy conversion; Storybook Test integrates testing workflows for components.  <hr />- **Commentary**: Insights on Lighthouse scores; discussion on headless components and CSS survey.  <hr />- **Quick Links**: Resources for continuous learning and exploration in frontend development advances.

227.title: Zaplib post-mortem
227.description: Zaplib is a frontend framework that helps to port your JS/TS app to Rust/Wasm. This idea was found after the founder's painful work at https://webviz.io when he had to use a bundle of manual memory management techniques such as ArrayBuffers, WebWorkers for performance optimization. Back up with the assumption that an intricate web app like Figma also uses Wasm, they thought there would be a lot of companies experiencing a similar performance issue with their applications and those companies would be keen on using their new tool to 10x speed up the apps.
227.spr_content: - Zaplib enables JS/TS apps to port to Rust/Wasm.<hr />- Founded from issues at Webviz, emphasizing manual memory management.<hr />- Assumed similar performance issues across complex web apps like Figma.<hr />- Aimed for 10x speed improvements, but results were disappointing.<hr />- Porting a JS simulator to Rust yielded only 5% performance increase.<hr />- Rust's advantages are limited to specific cases; faster memory layout and zero-cost abstractions are rare.<hr />- Typical performance gains are around 2x, not the anticipated 10x.<hr />- Successful migration attributed primarily to WebGL, not Rust/Wasm.<hr />- Figma's performance largely relies on WebGL, despite using C++/Wasm for file processing.<hr />- Considered shifting focus to WebGL, but market demand appears weak.<hr />- Doubts on startup viability and potential pivot to WebGL rerendering.

228.title: React Server Components, NextJs Route and Data Fetching
228.description: React Server Components (RSCs) offer the flexibility to decide where to render components based on their purpose, diverging from the client-side rendering approach of Single-Page Applications.
228.spr_content: - **React Server Components (RSCs):** Server-rendered components that enhance collaboration with Client Components.<hr />- **Stateless Design:** Focus on statelessness, run on server to optimize server and client transitions.<hr />- **Data Fetching Integration:** Supports top-level await, server-side data serialization, simplifying fetching processes.<hr />- **Performance and Size:** Improves performance, reduces bundle size, enhances initial load times, decreases JavaScript load.<hr />- **Next.js Role:** Leverages server-rendering, sends pre-built HTML to browsers for enhanced interactivity.<hr />- **File Naming Convention:** Use `.server.(jsx|tsx)` for Server Components, `.client.(jsx|tsx)` for Client Components.<hr />- **Boundary Directive:** `use client` marks client-only logic and separates server from client components in the codebase.<hr />- **Combining Components:** Server and Client Components coexist in the same tree; RSCs must be children prop in Client Components.<hr />- **Security Practices:** Utilize tools like `server-only` to protect sensitive server code from client exposure.<hr />- **Caching and Revalidation:** Next.js caches fetched data, supports background and on-demand revalidation.<hr />- **Server Actions:** Use `use server` in interactive handling functions for Client Components.<hr />- **Advanced Data Handling:** Consider using libraries like `SWR` or `React Query` for client-side data management; leverage React's `use()` for compatibility.<hr />- **Efficiency in Rendering:** RSCs offer an optimized rendering experience, paving the way for improved application performance and user experience.

229.file_path: playground/Frontend/Preserving and Resetting state in React.md
229.title: Preserving and Resetting state in React
229.description: State in React is tied to a position in the UI tree.
229.spr_content: - **Understanding React state**: Essential for effective component management.<hr />- **State locality**: State is linked to a component's position in the UI tree.<hr />- **Example structure**: `const [isPlayerA, setIsPlayerA] = useState(true)`. Demonstrates player state.<hr />- **Counter component**: Uses internal state (`score`) to reflect changes.<hr />- **Rendering approaches**:<hr />  - **Approach 1**: Shared state, same component, same tree position.<hr />  - **Approach 2**: Different tree positions for distinct counters.<hr />- **UI tree flow**: JSX → React → UI trees → React DOM → DOM.<hr />- **Shared state consequence**: Two counters at the same position retain independent states.<hr />- **State preservation criteria**: Same component, same position retains state.<hr />- **Component identity**: Different components at the same position reset state; e.g., switching from `Counter` to `p`.<hr />- **State reset mechanisms**:<hr />  - **Different positions**: Changes state effectively.<hr />  - **Using keys**: Unique keys prevent state sharing between similar components.<hr />- **Key usage**: Recommended to help differentiate and manage state.<hr />- **Implications of state management**: Errors arise when not resetting state appropriately.<hr />- **Reference for deeper learning**: React documentation link provided.

230.title: Mitigate blocking the main thread
230.description: We all know that for web applications, perceived performance is highly importance for our users. For data intensive SPAs with CPU-intensive tasks, the single-threaded nature of Javascript starts to hinder the application's perceived performance when you cannot fit those CPU-intensive tasks into a 16.67 ms/frame window (translates to 60fps). That doesn't even account for code execution time of frameworks (React, Vue...etc), which then leaves you with approximately only a 10 ms/frame window or less to complete all your tasks on the main thread to make user interaction feel smooth and snappy.
230.spr_content: - Perceived performance is crucial for user experience in web applications, especially in data-intensive SPAs.<hr />- CPU-intensive tasks in JavaScript suffer from single-threaded limitations, impacting smooth interaction.<hr />- The 60 frames per second (fps) standard translates to a maximum of 16.67 ms/frame for task completion.<hr />- Framework execution (e.g., React, Vue) further reduces usable time to about 10 ms/frame.<hr />- JavaScript offers solutions: Web Workers for threading and generators for coroutines.<hr />  <hr />## Web Workers<hr />- Web Workers enable offloading processing to another thread, enhancing main thread performance.<hr />- Serialization is a key drawback; data transmission between threads necessitates serialization, potentially blocking the main thread.<hr />- Suitable for small to medium data sets; advanced types like Shared Array Buffer mitigate some serialization issues.<hr />- Ideal for real-time applications needing regular data recalculations via game-loop-like functions for controlled data emission to the main thread.<hr /><hr />## Coroutines with Generators<hr />- Coroutines allow for suspended and resumed execution, running alongside other logic.<hr />- ES6 generators introduce pausing and resuming code with `yield`.<hr />- Example: Number generation up to 99 demonstrates yielding values.<hr />- For effective coroutine usage, combine generators with `requestIdleCallback()` to perform tasks only when the main thread is idle, maintaining performance.<hr />- Resources like js-coroutines provide implementations to address serialization challenges effectively.<hr /><hr />## References<hr />- MDN: Web Workers API, JavaScript Generators, requestIdleCallback documentation.

231.file_path: playground/Frontend/Retain scroll position in infinite scroll.md
231.title: Retain scroll position in infinite scroll
231.description: Infinite scroll has become a popular web design technique in recent years, as it offers several benefits over traditional pagination models. However, it can also present some painful challenges for accessibility and usability.
231.spr_content: - Infinite scroll: modern web design trend.  <hr />- Benefits: improved user experience, reduced page load times, fewer clicks.  <hr />- Challenges: accessibility issues, lost scroll position when navigating back.  <hr />- Example problem: user loses place after clicking item and returning to list.  <hr />- Proposed solution: retain scroll position using session storage.  <hr />- Key component: use `useSWRInfinite` for managing infinite scroll data.  <hr />- Store scroll position and SWR size before navigating away:  <hr />  - Function `handleSaveStates` stores `scrollPosition` and `swrSize` in session storage.  <hr />- Retrieve and restore position upon return:  <hr />  - Function `useRetainPosition` checks if stored data exists and updates scroll position and SWR size.  <hr />- Utilize two `useEffect` hooks:  <hr />  - First: scrolls to the saved position if valid.  <hr />  - Second: updates size of SWR if already loaded items exist.  <hr />- Effective user experience: user returns to the same scrolling position and data state.  <hr />- Avoid future scrolling issues by clearing session storage post-retrieval.  <hr />- Reference for implementation: [XKCD Infinite Scrolling](https://www.explainxkcd.com/wiki/index.php/1309:_Infinite_Scrolling).

232.title: Using Correct Html Element To Increase Website Accessibility
232.description: Using the correct HTML element can significantly improve the accessibility of your website.
232.spr_content:
- **Website Accessibility**: Focus on users with disabilities (e.g., visual impairments, literacy challenges).
- **Dependency**: Users rely on keyboard navigation or screen readers.
- **Quality Evaluation**: Accessibility is a criterion in Google Lighthouse assessments.
- **Developer Approach**: Enhance accessibility by categorizing website elements for reader identification and delivery.
- **Correct HTML Usage**: Utilizing appropriate HTML elements is crucial for accessibility.
- **Example of HTML Elements**: Prefer `` over `
Play video
`.
- **Benefits of Semantic HTML**:
1. **Enhanced Development**: Built-in functionality and clearer structure.
2. **Mobile Optimization**: Lighter and more responsive, reducing file size.
3. **Improved SEO**: Search engines prioritize semantic elements, increasing findability.

233.title: The fundamental of web performance
233.description: The key to improving your website speed is to understand where the bottlenecks are, and how much time each step takes.
233.spr_content: - Improve website speed by identifying bottlenecks and measuring time.<hr />- Key performance aspects: network latency and browser rendering.<hr />  <hr />**Network Latency:**<hr />- Definition: Time for request-response cycle between client and server.<hr />- Influencing factors: ISP speed, DNS lookup, TCP handshakes, server processing time, static asset requests.<hr />- High static assets lengthen load times. <hr /><hr />**Improvement Strategies:**<hr />- Position server close to client.<hr />- Optimize server response time: logic, cache.<hr />- Minimize file sizes: code splitting, compression.<hr />- Implement resource hints for preloading.<hr />- Utilize CDN for asset distribution.<hr /><hr />**Browser Rendering:**<hr />- Definition: Time to display page after data receipt.<hr />- Steps involved: parsing assets, pixel rendering.<hr /><hr />**Parsing Steps:**<hr />- Read HTML → build Document Object Model (DOM).<hr />- Read CSS → create Cascading Style Sheet Object Model (CSSOM).<hr />- Combine DOM and CSSOM for render tree creation.<hr /><hr />**Pixel Pipeline Operations:**<hr />- Algorithms that render visuals on screen, executed per state change.<hr />  <hr />**Major Areas of Focus:**<hr />1. **JavaScript:** Modifies the DOM (event listeners, elements).<hr />2. **Style Calculations:** Applies CSS rules.<hr />3. **Layout:** Positions elements (width, height, position).<hr />4. **Paint:** Renders visible elements.<hr />5. **Compositing:** Combines painted elements into a final frame.<hr /><hr />**Optimization Goal:**<hr />- Reduce rendering workload to enhance performance.<hr />- Understand browser handling of HTML, CSS, JavaScript phases.<hr />- Optimize CSS specificity for efficient style calculations.<hr /><hr />**References for further learning:**<hr />- Happy Browser, Happy User! by Katie Sylor Miller (Video).<hr />- web.dev resources on rendering performance and optimization techniques.

234.title: Scroll-driven animations
234.description: Scroll-driven animations are popular effects used in web design. They are animations that are connected to the scroll position of a scroll container.
234.spr_content: - Scroll-driven animations enhance web design, linking animations to scroll positions.<hr />- Annotations involve background movements and progress indicators; elements fade in with visibility.<hr />- Previous implementations suffered from performance issues due to main thread event handling.<hr />- Scroll-driven Animations specification introduces APIs for declarative animations.<hr />- Integration with Web Animations API and CSS Animations API is seamless.<hr />- **Animation Timelines**: <hr />  - Standard timeline runs on document load.<hr />  - **Scroll Progress Timeline**: <hr />    - Tied to scroll position; converts scroll range into progress percentage (0% at top, 100% at bottom).<hr />  - **View Progress Timeline**: <hr />    - Tracks visibility of elements within a scroller, begins at 0% upon entry, 100% upon exit.<hr />- Basic usage involves creating animations without JavaScript.<hr />- To define a Scroll Progress Timeline, use the `scroll()` function in CSS for animation-timeline settings.<hr />- Arguments for `scroll()` include:<hr />  - Scroller options: `nearest`, `root`, `self`.<hr />  - Axis options: `block`, `inline`, `y`, `x`.<hr />- Example setup: `animation: rotate auto linear; animation-timeline: scroll(root, block);`<hr />- Enabled in Chrome 115+ with 'Experimental Web Platform Features' required.<hr />- Potential for creative animations through Scroll-driven Animations. <hr />- Reference links provide additional resources and demos.

235.file_path: playground/Frontend/Applying Mock Service Worker (MSW) for Seamless Web Development.md
235.title: Applying Mock Service Worker (MSW) for Seamless Web Development
235.description: Mock Service Worker (MSW) is an API mocking library that leverages the Service Worker API to intercept requests. It offers unique features that set it apart from traditional mocking libraries, making it a go-to choice for developers. With MSW, you can seamlessly mock both RESTful and GraphQL APIs, providing flexibility for various API architectures. Additionally, MSW supports both Node.js and browser environments, enabling consistent API mocking across different parts of your application.
235.spr_content: - Mock Service Worker (MSW) is an API mocking library using the Service Worker API.<hr />- MSW uniquely intercepts both RESTful and GraphQL API requests, enhancing developer flexibility.<hr />- It operates seamlessly in both Node.js and browser environments, offering consistent API mocking.<hr />- Setting up MSW involves copying a worker file and initializing it with a CLI command: `npx msw init <PUBLIC_DIR> --save`.<hr />- Configure the worker by importing `setupWorker` and defining request handlers.<hr />- Start the worker in a development environment using conditional logic in application code.<hr />- Example: API request in `App` component using `useFetch` to manage data and errors.<hr />- MSW handlers mock API responses, allowing simulations of various requests and error conditions.<hr />- For React testing, MSW enables integration tests using a mocked server setup.<hr />- Include necessary setup using `setupServer()` and manage lifecycle with `beforeAll`, `afterEach`, and `afterAll` hooks.<hr />- Integration tests can use `screen.findByText` to assert mocked data is displayed correctly.<hr />- Runtime handlers can be added during tests for dynamic scenario testing, but will reset at cleanup.<hr />- MSW documentation available for further reference and detailed usage instructions.

236.file_path: playground/Frontend/When should we use useReducer instead of useState?.md
236.title: When should we use useReducer instead of useState?
236.description: Imagine we have a component with multiple states. It is simple enough not to use state management libraries. `useState` is surely a choice for the sake of brevity and clarity. But are there any issues we have to deal with? In this article, I want to make some improvements on `useState` hook and how we can replace it with `useReducer` as an alternative solution.
236.spr_content: - **Component State Management**: Components with multiple states can become unwieldy without state management libraries; `useState` is straightforward but has pitfalls.<hr />  <hr />- **Problems with `useState`**:<hr />  - Excessive `useState` hooks create clutter as state complexity increases.<hr />  - Lack of safeguards for state validity (e.g., choosing end date before start date).<hr />  <hr />- **Initial Code Improvement**: Consolidating states into a single object with `useState`:<hr />  ```jsx<hr />  const [event, setEvent] = useState({ title: ', description: ', attendees: [] });<hr />  ```<hr />  - Still requires care to avoid direct mutations and validation complexities.<hr /><hr />- **Enhanced Approach with Curried Function**:<hr />  - Handles state changes in a centralized and controlled manner.<hr />  - Requires awareness of multiple state update methods.<hr /><hr />- **Adopting `useReducer`**:<hr />  - Provides structured state updates and state validity guarantees.<hr />  - Centralized control over state transformations enhances maintainability:<hr />  ```jsx<hr />  const [event, updateEvent] = useReducer((prev, next) => ({ ...prev, ...next }), initialState);<hr />  ```<hr /><hr />- **Validation with `useReducer`**:<hr />  - Guarantees state conditions (e.g., date validation, max title length) in the reducer function.<hr /><hr />- **Flexibility of `useReducer`**:<hr />  - Capable of supporting complex state logic without adhering strictly to Redux patterns.<hr />  - Demonstrates simplicity in toggle mechanics, proving its versatility:<hr />  ```jsx<hr />  const [value, toggleValue] = useReducer(prev => !prev, false);<hr />  ```<hr /><hr />- **Immutability and Further Enhancements**:<hr />  - Encourages immutable state practices; libraries like `Immer` can mitigate complexity.<hr /><hr />- **Conclusion**: While `useState` is familiar and widely used, `useReducer` offers control over state transitions that is beneficial for developers managing complex state scenarios.

237.title: JavaScript modules
237.description: Modules have always been a part of JavaScript development and providing mechanisms for splitting JavaScript programs up into separate modules that can be imported when needed was the absolutely necessity for JavaScript developers.
